recipient_justification: Requesting three months of payments for January, February, and March for direct medical education and indirect medical education expenditures that includes resident’s salaries from the Children’s Hospital Graduate Medical Education (CHGME) Payment Program.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Each year, Boston Children’s Hospital trains more than 450 physician residents and clinical fellows in our accredited programs sponsored by and based at Boston Children’s, as well as more than 900 physician trainees from other hospitals rotating to BCH for their pediatric experience. These clinical fellows and residents receive critical education and training in over 40 clinical departments and 258 specialized clinical programs, including in Cardiology, Neurology, Sports Medicine, Orthopedics, Gastroenterology, Radiology, Emergency Medicine, and in many other areas where there are physician shortages. Our trainees are engaged in and responsible for the care of children that ranges from primary care to the management of medically complex and chronic health conditions.
The Children’s Hospital Graduate Medical Education funds BCH receives helps defray the costs of the essential education and training for these physician trainees participating in the BCH graduate medical education programs. It is the only source of government funding received by Boston Children’s Hospital (BCH) for the training of pediatricians and pediatric subspecialists. On an annual basis, CHGME funding received by BCH subsidizes approximately one third of the total training costs incurred by the institution.
Funding received through the CHGME program is critical to BCH’s ability to continue to offer effective and high-quality training in pediatrics and pediatric subspecialties. These funds allow BCH to pay for a portion of program administration costs, educational tools and educational offerings and help provide support for residents and clinical fellows while they participate in clinical care, including through salaries, stipends and benefits costs. The CHGME program operates on a reimbursement methodology, as opposed to prospective payment, meaning that Boston Children’s funds must be expended before payments can be invoiced and received from HRSA. These dollars fund the training of the next generation of pediatric health professionals and is critical in the health care delivery of complex, sick and vulnerable children. Many of our trainees go on to practice medicine in other parts of the country, where pediatric provider shortages are especially pronounced.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
The request for payment is made pursuant to Award from the Department of Health and Human Services, Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), to Southeast Missouri State University (SEMO). The statutory authority for the $10,000,000 award per SEMO’s 
What the Award is for:
SEMO’s Community Project Funding/Congressional Directed Spending (CPF/CDS) project will construct a new, multi-story, approximate 54,608-sf Health Sciences Building on an existing site owned by the SEMO in Cape Girardeau, MO. The building will include new classrooms, laboratories, clinical and other and experiential learning space, shared use facilities, and meeting venues to build and sustain the health care workforce. 

Why is the Project Necessary:
Pursuant to the project narrative submitted to HRSA as part of the grant making process, the Health Sciences Building will meet programmatic needs and expectations for students and faculty, and provide space for SEMO to enhance preprofessional and other training programs to meet existing and projected health workforce needs in Missouri and across the United States.  

The Missouri Economic Research and Information Center (MERIC) projects that many of the programs that will be served by the Health Sciences Building will experience employment growth in Missouri between now and 2028. For example, dietitians and nutritionists (10.14% growth), food scientists and technologists (4.47%), physical therapists (18.87%), registered nurses (16.24%) and physiologists (10.7%), among other fields and areas of study. Overall, MERIC data project that Healthcare Support Occupations will grow by 12.77% and Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Occupation by 13.08% between now and 2028. The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics projects similar growth at the national level over the next decade. The Health Sciences Building will allow SEMO to help meet these workforce needs. 

Many of the academic programs that will be served by the new Health Sciences Building are currently located in other facilities at SEMO that are experiencing significant structural and mechanical failures. Construction of the new Health Sciences Building will address these deficiencies while also ensuring SEMO continues to meet the programmatic needs and expectations for students, faculty, and current healthcare professionals.
 
The population groups to be served by the project include but may not be limited to: (1) students attending SEMO seeking to pursue a career in a STEM, health and life sciences, or allied health field; (2) practicing professional seeking continuing education and professional development or opportunities to engage with faculty or students in academic or research endeavors; and (3) members of the community that will benefit from a trained healthcare workforce.

If the Health Sciences Building is not constructed, the existing deficiencies and inadequacies of the current learning environment would continue, and SEMO’s ability to train and prepare the healthcare workforce would be significantly hindered. This would further impact the City of Cape Girardeau, the southeast Missouri region, and the State of Missouri, all of which are currently struggling to maintain adequate levels of staffing across many health-related occupations.

Breakdown of Amount Requested:

The reimbursement being requested at this time totals $1,730,339.57. The amounts included in this figure are consistent with stated purposes in Lines 4, 5 and 6 of Form SF424 and the Budget Narrative, both submitted to HRSA as part of the grant application in May 2023 and again in November 2023 in compliance with initial grant conditions. The amounts are as follows:

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
This Federal 330 Health Center Program Award funding is being used to provide primary care, medical, preventive dental, behavioral health, pharmacy, and ancillary services to medically underserved populations, including persons experiencing homelessness in the counties of Jackson, Platte, Clay, Ray, and Cass in the State of Missouri; as well as, Wyandotte and Leavenworth counties in the State of Kansas; as well as, the surrounding communities, in compliance with Section 330 of the Public Health Services Act.
These awarded funds are used to help pay for the salaries and fringe benefits of the clinical and non-clinical staff that are providing in scope services at in scope locations that are officially approved and supported by the Federal 330 grant awarded funds; as well as, indirect costs incurred to support this funding source, based on a Federally Approved Negotiated Indirect Cost Rate.
These awarded funds are necessary to support the clinical and non-clinical staff needed to provide the in scope services at in scope sites, required under our current Federal 330 Health Center Program Award funding.

recipient_justification: These funds support personnel costs for staff working to administer Pennsylvania’s approved Child and Family Services Plan. This $8942.12 payment covers staff salary ($5143.50) and associated benefits ($3798.62) for two positions for the period from March 29 to April 11, 2025.  These individuals are responsible for monitoring grantees, providing technical assistance, reporting, and continued development of the Maternal, Infant & Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) Program.  These payments support the delivery of evidence-based home visiting services to vulnerable and at-risk pregnant and parenting families in Pennsylvania; manage the Commonwealth's 24- hour toll-free helpline to provide resources that protect newborns who might otherwise be abandoned or harmed; deliver foundational (core) skills training to provide child welfare professionals with the fundamental awareness, understanding, knowledge, and skills needed to ensure adequate and accurate services to children and their families; and adoption promotion services.

recipient_justification: The Children's Hospitals Graduate Medical Education Payment (CHGME) program funds freestanding, children's hospitals. The money helps our graduate medical education (GME) programs train resident physicians.  CHGME hospitals receive two types of payments:  Direct Medical Education (DME) payments cover the direct cost of GME, such as stipends and fringe benefits for residents, and salaries and fringe benefits for faculty. Indirect Medical Education (IME) payments cover expenditures such as the cost of treating more severely ill patients and processing diagnostic tests because of the training of residents.

recipient_justification:
This grant supports operations of Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) in underserved communities. The funds are to be used to directly support Open Door Community Health Centers to provide comprehensive primary healthcare. ODCHC is the single largest provider of primary health care services in the two‐county area and provides the vast majority of primary care for the target population of low‐income, uninsured and publicly insured individuals unable to access care through the private sector.

April 2025 Expenses Breakdown:
Supplies- $197,510.36
Medical and dental supplies used in examinations and treatment, including pre/post-visit sterilization and sanitation procedures.
Contractual- $319,525.49
Locum tenens agency fees for provider vacancies to maintain and expand access based on available space.
Other- $25,177.98
Membership Fees for web-based medical reference resources, utilities, telephone expenses, and user licenses for electronic health record system. 

Thank you

recipient_justification:
The purpose of this HRSA H80 grant, or "Health Center Program," is to provide funding to domestic public or private, non-profit, community-based, and patient-directed organizations to deliver comprehensive primary healthcare services to vulnerable populations. The program aims to ensure continuous access to primary, preventive dental, behavioral health, and pharmacy services to underserved communities, in compliance with Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act.

This specific request is for funding that supports vital operations at Family Health Centers: a non-profit healthcare organization that consists of 6 health centers, 4 dental offices, and 2 pharmacies that serve the large rural, low income, remote region of Okanogan County, North Central Washington State. These funds pay the wages of most of our doctors, nurses, dentists, pharmacists, and other healthcare professionals, without whom the communities we serve would have little or no access to medical or dental care.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: We are requesting funding to ensure the ongoing provision of high-quality primary health care services to the underserved populations within the approved scope service area of Med Centro, Inc. These funds will be used for salaries and fringe benefits of our dedicated team, including doctors, nurses, behavioral health providers, clinical case managers and others. Additionally, the funds will cover the costs of patient medications, medical treatments, dental care, x-rays, and other essential supplies.

recipient_justification:
Request Type: Approval To Draw-Down Funds
Tracking Number: PA-00138246
Grant Number:CE1HS54340

TO: Department of Health and Human Services - Health Resource and Services Administration (HRSA)
FROM: The Richland Hospital, INC (TRH) (Award Number 6 CE1HS54340-01-05)
SUBJECT: Approval to Draw-Down Funds

The Federal Award Date for Grant Number CE1HS54340 (Richland Hospital & Clinics Community Project Funding/ Congressionally Directed Spending - Construction) was 09/23/2024.  Per THR’s NOA, the Project Period’s start date was 09/30/2024 with an ending date of 09/29/2027.  Approval to proceed with construction was received on 1/22/2025.

The Richland Hospital and Clinics is a community-sponsored, nonprofit, integrated primary care and specialty care clinic and critical access hospital, governed by a Board of Directors who oversee our activities, financial health and sustainability. Initially, the Board and Executive Management Team (EMT) discussed using CPF/CDS funding with our congressional representatives for a replacement facility. However, our plan has changed to renovating the current facility due to the increase in construction and material costs and not being able to design a building that would meet patient and staff needs while staying within budget. This change was relayed to our representatives to ensure that we would still meet CPF/CDS funding eligibility.

TRH’s BOD and Hospital Management based the scope of the project on the “Must Dos” list developed during the planning stage in early 2024. These projects will require coordination between multiple disciplines but tend to focus on individual types of projects throughout the interior and at the exterior of the building. Hospital leadership was highly focused on maintaining existing structures and took great pride in being good stewards of our resources, avoiding unnecessary duplication while identifying community needs. This project reconfirms the commitment Richland Hospital made to our community in 1924 as Richland County’s only hospital. Our future is built on creating a sustainable facility centered on the health and well-being of patients, which will meet our community’s current and future needs.

All costs requested for reimbursement, including pre-award costs were previously represented in the submitted proposal as well as the approved budget updates to HRSA These costs represent proper Project Costs and were necessary to complete all required components of the submittal process to access the awarded congressionally directed spending and are required in order to complete the construction associated with this project. The monies requested hereby are not greater than those necessary to meet obligations due and payable for Project Costs and do not include retention of monies not yet due under construction contracts.

The following submitted construction costs were incurred after receiving the NOA, granting approval to proceed with construction. The expenditures for which monies are requested hereby represent proper Project Costs, have not been included in a previous Requisition Certificate and have been properly recorded on TRH’s books.

Detailed costs are as follows:
Dates of Service: 03/01/2025 - 03/3102025
Firm(s) Paid by TRH			Amount Paid		Goods or Services Provided  
Market & Johnson			$452,539.95		Construction
Lines 8 & 9 of the approved budget (SF-424c) 
								Demolition & construction.
BWBR					$6,417.00		Architectural & Engineering Fees
Line 4 of SF-424c
Design services of the renovated space. Administration of the construction documents.
Medcraft Healthcare Real 		$4,62.00		Project Management Services
Estate, LLC 							Line 5 of SF-424c
Coordination of work phasing and project management	

TRH has invoices of the services provided by the above vendors.  TRH was initially advised that the invoices, as long as they were a part of the approved proposal, did not need to be uploaded.  The Market & Johnson invoice provides detailed information, including specific costs for demolition, building works, membrane roofing, fire caulk materials, painting and coating, casework, plumbing and electrical. BWBR and Medcraft’s invoices have provided the breakdown of provided professional services.

Please advise us as to whether these detailed invoices are required and, if so, confirm whether they are to be uploaded as part of the payment request process.

recipient_justification:
Funding Justification for a Durable Medical Equipment Loan Locker in Alaska
A Community-Based Solution That Saves Money and Strengthens Alaska

Overview
A Durable Medical Equipment (DME) Loan Locker provides free, short-term access to essential medical equipment like wheelchairs, walkers, hospital beds, and shower chairs. This program is a cost-effective, community-driven solution that addresses major gaps in Alaska’s healthcare system — especially in remote and rural areas.

It empowers local residents, reduces emergency response strain, and keeps people safe at home, all while saving taxpayer money and extending the life of valuable equipment.

1. Alaska’s Equipment Access Crisis
In Alaska, getting medical equipment isn’t a matter of days it’s often a matter of months.

Shipping Delays: Most DME comes from out of state. Due to long shipping routes, weather issues, and limited freight options, even basic equipment can take 2 to 8 weeks to arrive. In off-road or remote communities, it can take longer — sometimes 2 to 3 months.

Insurance Bottlenecks: Even with coverage, people wait 4 to 6 weeks for doctor approvals, insurance authorizations, and supplier coordination before shipping begins.

Limited Local Supply: Outside of Anchorage and Fairbanks, there are few DME providers. For many, the only option is to travel or go without putting them at risk of injury or hospitalization.

2. A Smarter Way to Support Alaskans
A DME Loan Locker changes the game by making equipment available immediately — no shipping, no red tape. Local nonprofits or community health organizations can manage the lockers, sanitizing and reissuing donated or lightly-used equipment.

This model:

Reduces costs for families and healthcare systems

Keeps seniors, veterans, and people with disabilities safe at home

Prevents unnecessary emergency room visits and hospital readmissions

Fosters a self-reliant, sustainable approach to rural health care

3. Easing the Load on Emergency and Public Resources
Without proper equipment, people often rely on emergency services for basic needs:

911 calls for help with mobility or falls

Emergency room visits for injuries that could have been prevented

Fire departments asked to assist with lifting or home safety checks

These situations are avoidable. Providing walkers, shower chairs, and safety tools reduces these calls and lets our first responders focus on true emergencies. A DME Loan Locker is a practical, efficient solution that saves lives and resources.

4. Supporting Veterans, Seniors, and Working Families
This program directly benefits those who have given so much:

Veterans who deserve access to mobility and independence

Seniors aging in place with dignity

Low-income families facing medical emergencies with no support

Rural residents who live hours from the nearest equipment provider

It’s about helping people help themselves — without handouts, without expanding government, and without adding costs to the system.

5. A Program That Pays for Itself
Most of the equipment in a Loan Locker can be:

Donated by hospitals, families, or the VA

Refurbished, sanitized, and reused multiple times

Distributed quickly and locally

It’s a one-time infrastructure investment with long-term payoff. It reduces Medicaid and Medicare spending, hospital burden, and emergency room overload — while building a culture of community care and common sense.

Conclusion: A Proven, Conservative Solution for Alaska
The DME Loan Locker is exactly the kind of project that works in Alaska:

Locally managed

Low cost, high impact

Efficient, sustainable, and people-focused

It’s not about more government, it’s about smarter government. It’s a win for public health, emergency readiness, and taxpayer dollars.

Support for this initiative is support for Alaska families, veterans, and first responders. It’s the kind of solution that works for real Americans, and keeps Alaska strong.

Payment Justification for Subaccounts 24T91HP25784, 24T91HP25781, 24T91HP25780, 24T91HP53248 (Teaching Health Center Program):

The requested funds are necessary to support approved activities under our HRSA Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education (THCGME) award. These funds will be used to cover the following:

Salaries and fringe benefits for primary care medical residents

Faculty and preceptor compensation for supervising community-based training

Administrative support staff involved in managing the THC program

Training-related costs such as medical liability insurance, educational materials and rotations

These expenditures are directly aligned with the purpose of the THCGME award—to expand community-based primary care training and strengthen the pipeline of providers in underserved areas. All costs are consistent with our approved budget and allowable under 45 CFR Part 75 and HRSA’s award terms.

Expenditures	 
Payroll (Residents, Preceptors, Staff)	705,728
Fringe Benefits	120,833
Occupancy	19,333
Supplies & Materials	458
Resident Mtgs, Information, Educational Stipends & Conferences	51,732
Computers, Maintenance, Supplies & Materials	5,208
Insurances	27,841
Rotations & Contracted Services	116,667

This project remodels an existing suite to establish a new FQHC site, transforming the space into a fully functional, patient-centered primary care clinic that meets HRSA and all federal and state health and safety requirements. This draw request represents the final payment for construction services rendered. Funded through Congressionally Directed Spending under the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, the project aligns with the intent of the capital grant program to expand access to quality health care in underserved communities.

The use of capital grant funds from the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2022, for this remodeling project is fully justified as it directly supports the strategic goals of the federal appropriations and EO14222. This investment will strengthen the health care safety net, promote equitable access, and contribute to the long-term health and economic resilience of an underserved community

recipient_justification:
This HRSA funding supports the development of Arcadia University's Anatomy Resource Center (AARC). The AARC initiative serves approximately 300+ students in our nationally ranked Physical Therapy (PT) and Physician Assistant programs. PT students also work in our campus’ interdisciplinary pro-bono physical therapy clinic which serves nearly 150 Pennsylvanians per year. It also provides estimated 50-60 undergraduate and 30-60 high school students rare access to study human specimens annually.
We are on schedule with the project and have procured the multiple needed items as planned. We procured and deployed through the approved funds classroom audio/video equipment and commercial display monitors in the Anatomy Resource Lab and Anatomy Resource Clean Room. Chairs, tributaire lecterns, etc., were obtained and deployed for the AARC Simulation Laboratory Monitoring Station in mid-August.
 We also procured and deployed industrial stools for the AARC Biology Lab and the AARC Chemistry Lab. recipient_justification:
Justification for HRSA Grant Reimbursement
Payment ID: 4040558811
FAIN: T2946721 / 22T29HP46721C6
Subaccount: 22T29HP46721C6
Total Reimbursement Requested: $325,209.68

Program Overview
This HRSA-funded initiative supports the training of Community Health Workers (CHWs) who will serve individuals with disabilities in rural communities across Tennessee. The program addresses workforce shortages by preparing local residents for entry-level healthcare roles that support care coordination, resource navigation, and health promotion.

The training model emphasizes practical skills, field experience, and regional service alignment. Participants are recruited from rural counties and complete short-term, certificate-based training through Tennessee Colleges of Applied Technology (TCATs) and community colleges. The program is designed to be time-limited and goal-oriented, with clear milestones to encourage timely completion.

Expense Breakdown and Justification

Expense Category	Amount	Justification
Participant Stipends	$219,000.00	Issued directly to learners as financial support during training and to incentivize program completion. Stipends help offset costs such as transportation, childcare, and time away from work.
Salary	$45,469.02	Covers the wages of the program coordinator and specialist who provide daily program oversight, manage student support services, and monitor progress. The project manager’s salary is not charged to this grant.
Admin Fees	$30,888.00	Paid to a third-party fiscal vendor responsible for processing individual stipend checks, issuing tax forms (e.g., 1099s), and ensuring proper documentation of payments.
Benefits	$13,752.66	Fringe benefits associated with the salaries of the coordinator and specialist, including employer-paid health and retirement contributions.
Tuition	$16,100.00	Payment of tuition and fees for learners enrolled in approved training programs at TCATs and community colleges.
Conclusion
The total requested reimbursement of $325,209.68 reflects allowable, documented expenses in support of a targeted health workforce initiative. All costs align with the approved budget narrative and serve the grant’s objective of preparing individuals in rural areas to support healthcare access for people with disabilities. This submission does not include any personnel costs for the project manager, and all stipend payments and administrative functions were managed through a contracted third party to ensure accuracy and compliance.

Please let me know if additional documentation is needed.

recipient_justification:
This proposal seeks funding in the amount of $300,000 to support the delivery of comprehensive primary, preventive dental, and behavioral health services across 21 counties in southwestern Mississippi. These areas are designated as medically underserved and face significant barriers to accessing quality healthcare. The proposed activities are consistent with the mission and requirements of Delta State Rural  network, which supports community-based health services in underserved communities.
1. Personnel Costs – $81,741.68
This funding will support the salaries of healthcare providers and support staff critical to the delivery of integrated health services. Personnel covered include community health workers, dental hygienists, behavioral health counselors, and administrative staff, all of whom play vital roles in increasing access to care and improving patient outcomes.
2. Fringe Benefits – $16,440.77
Fringe benefits are essential to attract and retain qualified professionals in high-need areas. These benefits include health insurance, retirement contributions, and other employment-related obligations necessary to ensure a stable and motivated workforce.
3. Supplies – $15,290.55
Funds in this category will be used to procure essential medical, dental, and behavioral health supplies needed to provide high-quality preventive and treatment services. This includes personal protective equipment (PPE), diagnostic tools, health education materials, and clinical consumables.
4. Program Implementation – $186,527.00
This portion of the request will support the implementation and expansion of health programs designed to address the specific needs of the population. Activities include community outreach, mobile health unit operations, chronic disease prevention initiatives, mental health screenings, and oral health education. These programs are essential for improving health equity and reducing long-term healthcare costs through prevention and early intervention.
Total Request: $300,000.00
This funding will strengthen the healthcare infrastructure in southwestern Mississippi, promote integrated and patient-centered care, and align with the federal objective of ensuring access to health services for vulnerable and underserved populations.

recipient_justification:
Per Public Law 117-328, The Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) Grant is used to support title III of the Public Health Service Act in Washington state to to improve coordination of services for at-risk communities, as well as, identify and provide comprehensive services to improve outcomes for eligible families who reside in at-risk communities. 
The program builds upon decades of scientific research that shows home visits conducted by a nurse, social worker, early childhood educator, or other trained professional during pregnancy and in the first years of a child’s life improves the lives of children and families. Home visiting helps prevent child abuse and neglect, supports positive parenting, improves maternal and child health, and promotes child development and school readiness. The MIECHV program plays a crucial role in building high quality, comprehensive statewide early childhood systems to support pregnant women, parents and caregivers, and children from birth to kindergarten entry and ultimately, to improve health and development outcomes.

Payment Justification for Subaccounts 24T91HP25784, 24T91HP25781, 24T91HP25780, 24T91HP53248 (Teaching Health Center Program):

The requested funds are necessary to support approved activities under our HRSA Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education (THCGME) award. These funds will be used to cover the following:

Salaries and fringe benefits for primary care medical residents

Faculty and preceptor compensation for supervising community-based training

Administrative support staff involved in managing the THC program

Training-related costs such as medical liability insurance, educational materials and rotations

These expenditures are directly aligned with the purpose of the THCGME award—to expand community-based primary care training and strengthen the pipeline of providers in underserved areas. All costs are consistent with our approved budget and allowable under 45 CFR Part 75 and HRSA’s award terms.

Payroll (Residents, Preceptors, Staff)	705,728
Fringe Benefits	120,833
Occupancy	19,333

Computers, Maintenance, Supplies & Materials	5,208
Insurances	27,841
Rotations & Contracted Services	116,667
Transportation	1,000
Total Expenditures	1,048,800

recipient_justification:
Payment Justification for Subaccounts 24T91HP25784, 24T91HP25781, 24T91HP25780, 24T91HP53248 (Teaching Health Center Program):

The requested funds are necessary to support approved activities under our HRSA Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education (THCGME) award. These funds will be used to cover the following:

Salaries and fringe benefits for primary care medical residents

Faculty and preceptor compensation for supervising community-based training

Administrative support staff involved in managing the THC program

Training-related costs such as medical liability insurance, educational materials and rotations

These expenditures are directly aligned with the purpose of the THCGME award—to expand community-based primary care training and strengthen the pipeline of providers in underserved areas. All costs are consistent with our approved budget and allowable under 45 CFR Part 75 and HRSA’s award terms.

Expenditures	 
Payroll (Residents, Preceptors, Staff) 705,728
Fringe Benefits	120,833
Occupancy	19,333
Supplies & Materials	458
Resident Mtgs, Information, Educational Stipends & Conferences	51,732
Computers, Maintenance, Supplies & Materials	5,208
Insurances	27,841
Rotations & Contracted Services	116,667
Transportation	1,000
Total Expenditures	1,048,800

recipient_justification: The project contains the following elements. At the Jordan Center: installation of a generator so support critical systems replacing the building's original generator for which parts are no longer available; painting of common areas; and replacement of flooring throughout the building. The drawdown covers the following expenses: Jordan Center generator: $65,276.00; Jordan Center painting: $15,650.00; Jordan Center flooring: $63,732.15; Woodward Center generator: $58,388.99; Woodward Center painting: $10,000.00; Woodward Center flooring: $38,752.92.

recipient_justification: •	This program aims to enhance obstetric care coordination by addressing the clinical needs of patients at the highest risk for maternal morbidity and mortality. By supporting comprehensive care from the first prenatal visit through 18 months postpartum, the program seeks to improve OB care outcomes for Sam Rodgers’s patient population. Grant funds will support a multidisciplinary staffing model, including Clinical Care Coordinators, OB Behavioral Health Consultants, an Ultrasound Technician, and an RN Case Manager. In addition to staffing, the funds will cover essential supplies and operational costs necessary to deliver high-quality care, in alignment with the standards required of a Federally Qualified Health Center under HRSA Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act.

The purpose of this award is to develop and deliver training and technical assistance that will support health centers in improving the health of individuals and communities by: (1) Increasing access to comprehensive, high-quality primary health care services; (2) Recruiting and retaining the health center workforce; (3) Preparing for, responding to, and recovering from emergent health events; (4) Implementing value-based care delivery and ensuring financial sustainability; and (5) Accelerating data-informed improvements to operations, clinical quality, and care coordination.

On this payment request, the vast majority of funds requested under subaccount 24U58CS06824 represent staffing-related costs for the work our staff team has done to carry out the award purposes described above. A small portion of the requested funds represents non-staffing-related costs and includes consultants, supplies, and travel costs to carry out the award purposes described above.

recipient_justification:
Please see the requested information below, and advise if this is specific enough, or if more information is needed:

The purpose of the DIBH Workforce Training Program is to increase the number of graduating MSWs trained in, and committed to, post-graduate professional practice in communities which meet HRSA's definition of rural or medically underserved community (MUC).  

Stipends: The bulk of the DIBH Workforce Training Program budget, as required by HRSA, is spent on the provision of MSW student trainee stipends.  These stipends to participants support their eduactional support related costs, and are necessary in meeting the grant deliverables. 

Payroll: Payroll costs support daily program administration, evaluation activities, faculty trainers, recruitment, and an interprofessional workgroup focused on increasing interdepartmental opportunities for interprofessional exposure and activities for students. These expenditures are necessary for program support and to meet grant deliverables.

Contracts (non-state): Contractual costs have included training consultants, field placement management software, and curriculum development. These activities all support the DIBH training program activities and deliverables.

Student Wages:  Doctor of Social Work students have provided support on this grant in activities including providing external field supervision for DIBH program trainees, providing mentorship and job search support for trainees, reviewing literature and collecting data on training needs of field supervisors, program data collection and analysis, and completing literature reviews and drafting manuscripts for publication on topics to support the grant (professional adaptation of social workers in integrated care settings and understanding the service needs of transitional aged youth with autism and their families). These activities are essential in supporting this grant program.

Travel:  Travel funds have supported faculty in attending research and social work education focused conferences to strengthen the grant program and to network with other HRSA grantees in sharing outcomes and lessons learned in program implementation and sustainability.

recipient_justification: In compliance with Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act, our Federal Award, NOA FAIN# H8000549, pays for a portion of the salaries of our providers in providing primary care, dental and behavior health services to our patients, which mostly includes Medicaid and uninsured patients at our FQHC clinics in southern Maryland.  Specifically, this PMS request of $219,575.20 partially pays the salaries of physicians, nurse practitioners, dentists, nurses and medical assistants.  This expense is only salaries and is related to the last payroll that was completed last week.  This payment is necessary due to the high level of patients seen without insurance or the ability to pay, but are in need of medical care, which we provide regardless of their ability to pay.  We incur the total cost of their care, as a safety net, and this award is to help offset some of that cost so that these patients can receive care and healing and do not end up in a worst medical condition, which is regretful for them and may end up costing the healthcare system more in the long run through more expensive means, such as Emergency room visits, etc.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Our health center, a Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC), is requesting funds to cover the salaries of our current healthcare providers and support staff.  These expenses are detailed in our federally approved workplan and budget, ensuring continuity of care in our medically underserved community.
The requested $201,278.50 will be allocated as follows:  $153,758.83 for salaries of existing healthcare providers as well as $47,519.67 for nursing support staff for the two-week pay period ended April 25, 2025.  These costs are outlined in our federally approved workplan and budget.
These funds will be utilized immediately upon receipt to cover these salaries.  Our health center has established policies to ensure that funds drawn down are spent appropriately.  These funds help to cover the salaries of our healthcare providers and support staff resulting in sustained patient care and improved health outcomes in our community.

recipient_justification: The purpose of the award is to provide medical, dental and behavioral health services to underserved patients who do not have insurance to pay for these services.  The funds are used to pay salaries and benefits for medical, dental and behavioral health providers such as physicians, dentists, dental hygienists and support staff.  These expenditures are necessary because these services are provided to underserved patients based on a sliding fee scale under which patients with income below 200% of the federal poverty level pay only between $30 and $75 per visit.   These payments average about $60 per visit, which is far below the average cost of a visit, which is about $354.

The grant funds were utilized to support the delivery of essential clinical services in alignment with the cost-reimbursable structure of HRSA-funded healthcare programs. Specifically, these funds were applied to partially cover salaries and wages of medical, dental, and behavioral health (BH) providers, as well as their associated support staff, who deliver direct patient care to underserved populations.
During the reporting period, the grant-supported staffing and service delivery included the following:

Medical Services:
•	Staffing: 10 Medical Providers, 8 Registered Nurses, and 20 Care Team Support Staff
•	Service Volume: 2,974 patient visits
•	Grant Use: Funds were used to offset a portion of salaries for these clinical staff who directly contributed to the delivery of medical care, enabling continuity and access to high-quality services.

Dental Services:
•	Staffing: 8 Dental Hygienists and 45 Dental Support Staff
•	Service Volume: 3,676 patient visits
•	Grant Use: Salaries and wages of dental hygienists and support personnel were partially reimbursed through the grant, supporting preventive and restorative oral health services.

Behavioral Health Services:
•	Staffing: 20 Licensed Mental Health Clinicians, 2 Psychiatric Providers, and 1 Substance Use Disorder Counselor
•	Service Volume: 2,077 patient visits
•	Grant Use: The grant covered a portion of compensation for behavioral health professionals engaged in counseling, psychiatric evaluation, and substance use treatment.

The use of grant funds is fully consistent with HRSA guidance for allowable costs under cost-reimbursable grants, and directly supports the objective of expanding access to comprehensive, integrated primary care services. By funding a share of provider and support staff salaries, the grant helped ensure the availability of critical services, sustained staffing levels, and reduced barriers to care for vulnerable populations.

recipient_justification:
The payment request of $175,360.75 is comprised of the following items:

1. Payroll Costs - $14,372.65 for salaries and wages of a program director at 0.3 FTE and two Certified Peer Support Specialists (CPSS) at 1.0 FTE each, for a total of 2.3 FTE
2. Fringe Benefits Costs - $1,707.62 for fringe benefits for FICA, paid time off, insurance, and retirement contribution matching for the 2.3 FTEs discussed above, all of which are organizational employee benefits
3. Grant Staff Training - $611.95 for Question, Persuade, and Refer (QPR) training for one CPSS; QPR is a suicide prevention program aimed to provide the knowledge and skills needed to recognize the warning signs of suicide and intervene effectively; one CPSS has already received this training, however, the organization has seen 7 suicide attempts in the last two months, three of which were successful, which highlights the need for both CPSS's to be trained in QPR to better serve the employee population
4. Contracts: TTUHSC - $3,799.50 for psychiatric coverage for employees assessed by the CPSS's as requiring a greater level of care; $2,199.75 of this is for January 2025 coverage and $1,599.75 is for February 2025 coverage; coverage costs will vary depending on the number of employees requiring the greater level of care each month
5. Contracts: Healthsource Solutions - $307.20 for monthly enrollment costs of 128 members into the organization's current wellness platform, which includes generalized challenges and resources for physical, mental, social, and financial health; this is an expansion of the organization's existing wellness initiatives, and federal funds are used only for the cost of enrollment for employees in previously excluded categories, such as on-call/PRN employees and UMC Physicians staff, as written and approved in the grant application submission
6. Contracts: MeQuilibrium - $154,560.00 for annual subscription to the MeQuilibrium platform, which is available to all organization employees, providing targeted challenges and resources for each enrollee based on quarterly assessments which identify specific "drags" or areas of concern for that individual; de-identified data is available to the organization to analyze the utilization and effectiveness of this platform; this platform has been the most successful initiative in the grant program, with high utilization, improved metrics over time, and high satisfaction rates on the employee wellness survey
Indirect Costs - $1.83 of postage expense for mailing program staff W2's
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
This payment request supports March 2025 expenditures under the RCORP Children & Adolescent Behavioral Health (CABH) grant, in alignment with the approved scope of work to expand access to behavioral health services for youth in rural Georgia.

Personnel & Fringe: Covers salaries and fringe for staff supporting after-school behavioral health programming, coordination, and outreach across multiple service sites.

Travel: Includes local travel for Unison vans used to transport children and youth to and from after-school programs, as well as costs for meals and travel for Project Director attending RCORP program meeting in Washington DC.

Supplies: Includes costs to meet the nutritional needs of youth in the after school behavioral health program, activity supplies to support the therapeutic needs of the youth in the afterschool program, educational materials, and First Aid/BLS certification required for program safety and readiness.

Contractual (Share Health/Data Collection):  Data collection for school system and family connections participation (Coffee and Atkinson Counties) to fulfill HRSA reporting requirements and program evaluation on ongoing needs and challenges, coordinated by Share Health Southeast Georgia.

Patient Benefits:  Provided hygiene kits for youth in Clinch, Atkinson, and Coffee counties to meet essential needs that may go unmet at home, supporting consistent engagement in services.

Equipment/Mobile Van:  Purchase of a mobile van to be retrofitted as a therapeutic service environment. The van will be customized with telehealth capabilities and trauma-informed design features to provide accessible care in rural areas.

Other:  Includes costs for electronic health record (Carelogic) and Microsoft 365 licenses, mobile phone service, internet access, Eleos AI tools, and onboarding expenses (e.g., background checks, fingerprinting) for newly hired grant-funded staff.

Indirect Costs:   Calculated at 10% of eligible direct costs, supporting grant administration and compliance.

All expenditures occurred in March 2025 and are necessary to fulfill the CABH program’s objectives of increasing access, engagement, and support for youth behavioral health services in underserved rural communities.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
The Delta Program provides grant funding to support the planning, development, and
implementation of integrated health care networks that collaborate in order to (i) achieve
efficiencies; (ii) expand access to, coordinate, and improve the quality of basic health
care services and associated health outcomes in rural areas within the eight rural
Mississippi Delta Region states (Alabama, Arkansas, Illinois, Kentucky, Louisiana,
Mississippi, Missouri, and Tennessee); and (iii) strengthen the rural health care system
as a whole.
The goals of the Delta Program are to:
• Expand access to care resources in the designated Mississippi Delta
counties/parishes;
• Utilize evidence-based, promising practice, or value-based care models known to
improve health outcomes, and enhance the delivery of health care services;
• Collaborate with network partners in the planning, delivery, and evaluation of
health care services to increase access to care and reduce chronic disease; and
• Implement sustainable health care programs that improve population health,
health outcomes, and demonstrate value to the local rural communities.

recipient_justification:
This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount Number - 20SDS (the “Award”) for work performed between 7/1/2020 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $159,145.93. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award. 
 
Item	Cost
Scholarship costs	$159,145.93
Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$159,145.93

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science.  According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS).

The objective of this Award is to support the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science’s (CDU) College of Nursing (CON) program by providing scholarships and retention support to nursing students. The program aims to achieve the following clinical objectives:
•	Scholarship Provision: Annually provide scholarships to 32 nursing students, totaling 128 students over the award period, to facilitate their education and training in the nursing field.
•	Student Retention and Support: Implement strategies to retain 90% of CON students by offering comprehensive support services alongside financial aid, ensuring students have the resources needed to succeed academically and clinically.
•	Graduation and Licensure Success: Graduate at least 35 scholarship recipients, with a target of 90% passing their licensure exams, thereby contributing to a well-qualified nursing workforce.
•	Primary Care Practice: Encourage at least 60% of graduates to enter primary care practice, addressing critical healthcare needs and enhancing the delivery of primary care services.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: Funds through NOA FPHPA6565A are used to provide family planning and related preventative health care to assist individuals in freely determining the number and spacing of their children through the promotion of positive birth outcomes and healthy families, assisted by education, counseling, and medical services. Family planning clinical services are confidential reproductive health services provided at low/no-cost in public health offices statewide and some community and school-based health centers. Clinical services include birth control, counseling, and laboratory tests. Required services through Title X include: the provision of a broad range of FDA-approved, acceptable, and effective family planning methods; education and counseling related to family planning; clinical procedures, as indicated, for the prescribed method; laboratory testing, as indicated, for the prescribed method; and level 1 infertility services. The funds also provide for gynecological services and STI/HIV scree

recipient_justification:
This payment request pertains to funds allocated under our current HRSA award, which supports the delivery of integrated, community-based healthcare and supportive services to underserved and vulnerable populations.
In accordance with the scope and objectives outlined in our Notice of Award, these funds are being used to provide a comprehensive continuum of care that directly advances the federal priorities outlined in Executive Order 14222, including health equity, behavioral health integration, and access to essential services. Our current activities include:
•	Medical Care and Screenings: Provision of primary care, preventive services, immunizations, and diagnostic screenings designed to reduce health disparities and improve population health outcomes.
•	Substance Use Disorder Services: Delivery of outpatient treatment and recovery support services aligned with federal goals on behavioral health and opioid response.
•	Case Management and Eligibility Assistance: Navigation support for public program enrollment and care coordination to improve long-term access and health system utilization.
•	Health Education and Outreach: Targeted community outreach to promote public health literacy, preventive care engagement, and early intervention.
•	Dental Care: Provision of preventive and basic oral healthcare to support whole-person care and reduce emergency room dependence for dental conditions.
•	Mental Health Services: Individual and group therapy, along with crisis support services, to address community behavioral health needs.
These expenditures support operational costs including personnel, clinical supplies, and facility expenses, and are consistent with the intent and allowable uses of HRSA funding as detailed in our award documentation. We believe this draw request is fully justified and aligned with applicable federal guidance and priorities under EO 14222
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: Project staff for the Enhancing Systems of Care for Children with Medical Complexity Coordinating Center (ESC CC) focused on preparations for Learning Session 10, continued support of the Demonstration Site engagement teams through FESAT scoring sessions, and conducted 15-minute check-ins with each Demonstration Site to confirm survey implementation and next steps. Learning Session 10 was designed to provide helpful insights regarding value-based care structures for supporting children with medical complexity. Demonstration Sites teams received direct technical assistance and began brainstorming additional ideas for further applications to their care sites. The ESC CC Team also developed a detailed outline for the Engaging Medicaid to Enhance Systems of Care for CMC Toolkit. This detailed outline was shared with HRSA in early March. While the detailed outline is under review by HRSA, partners, and subject matter experts, the ESC CC team has begun building out toolkit content.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: The purpose of the award is to provide medical, dental and behavioral health services to underserved patients who do not have insurance to pay for these services.  The funds are used to pay salaries and benefits for medical, dental and behavioral health providers such as physicians, dentists, dental hygienists and support staff.  These expenditures are necessary because these services are provided to underserved patients based on a sliding fee scale under which patients with income below 200% of the federal poverty level pay only between $30 and $75 per visit.   These payments average about $60 per visit, which is far below the average cost of a visit, which is about $354.

recipient_justification:
Total Payment Request: $129,094.87

Award #1: Health Center Program Grant
•	Award Number: H80CS28956-10-00
•	Requested Amount: $94,494.87
•	Award Date: 04/24/2024
•	Project Title: Health Center Program
•	Purpose: Payroll Expenses  
This payment will be exclusively used for payroll to support the ongoing critical operations of six Federally Qualified Health Centers serving the greater metropolitan area in Phoenix, Arizona. The payroll is used to pay health center employees, including clinic providers and medical administrators, ensuring the continuing provision of care for thousands of patients receiving primary care and behavioral health services, including specialty services like birth-to-five programming, serious mental illness case management, and methadone clinics. This payment is strictly for earned income payroll distributions; it is not used to fund fringe benefits or other distributions.

Award #2: Quality Improvement Supplement
•	Award Number: H80CS28956-10-03
•	Requested Amount: $33,600.00
•	Award Date: 05/30/2024
•	Project Title: Supplement for Quality Improvement
•	Purpose: One-time grant supplement for FY 2024 Quality Improvement Award: Uniform Data System Patient-Level Submission (QIA: UDS+)
This payment is requested as a one-time grant supplement to support our HRSA-funded health center in adopting new software to collect high-quality, patient-level data. The data will be used to track and improve UDS implementation and reporting, and to support risk assessments and risk management protocols.  The goal of this funding request is to allow our health center to improve compliance with federal directives and to mitigate risk through improved data collection.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
The requested funds were used to provide critical subsistence and training support, in alignment with the HRSA-22-124 CHWTP Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO): Reduce barriers to program enrollment and retention through direct financial support for subsistence needs, as authorized under NOFO pg. 14 (“Reduce barriers to CHW and health support worker program enrollment and retention by providing eligible trainees with participant support e.g., tuition/fees, stipends, health insurance, and child care”).

Provide wraparound support such as mentoring, case management, and financial assistance (stipends and direct supports) to help trainees overcome barriers to success, as described on NOFO pg. 14 (“Provide wraparound support to help trainees overcome barriers to success, such as mentoring and financial support”).

Ensure all trainees receiving participant support were fully enrolled in the approved CHWTP training program, consistent with NOFO pg. 10 (“Trainees supported by CHWTP receiving financial support must be enrolled full- or part-time in the school or program receiving the CHWTP grant funding”).

All expenditures complied with allowable uses of funds as outlined in the HRSA Grants Policy Bulletin 2022-05E, specifically adhering to legislative mandates regarding:

No expenditures for prohibited activities (e.g., lobbying, gun control advocacy, abortion services).

Salary limitations and proper acknowledgment of federal funding.

recipient_justification:
The Rural Communities Opioid Response Program (RCORP) provides grant funding to support two rural outpatient Medication Assisted Treatment (MAT) clinics in Jacksonville, IL and Taylorville, IL.  In addition, the program develops an Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME)-accredited addiction medicine fellowship with a rural emphasis to strengthen the workforce and increase the sustainability and implementation of existing and new addiction services in the region.

The goals of the RCORP program are to:
•	Establish new MAT access points.
•	Enhance the MAT workforce, through recruitment, training, and peer mentorship.
•	Build community capacity and infrastructure to support MAT services.
•	Ensure sustainability of new MAT access points through billing and coding.

We are requesting reimbursement for the period 03/20/2025 - 04/23/2025 for the approved budget categories in the the notice of award: Salary and Wages, Fringe Benefits, Travel, Consortium/Contractual Costs, Other, and Indirect Costs.

recipient_justification:
Southern Healthcare Collaboration, Inc. is a nonprofit agency working to support the rural healthcare provider clinical integration and network infrastructure, enabling the stressed healthcare system to expand outreach and increase access to care for rural communities.  Treatment and recovery expansions funded through RCORP-Impact address the need for Substance Use Disorder services that reach adults, children, and adolescents, strengthening the web of services available, increasing case load capacity, and reducing waiting periods for Americans in rural communities. In total, 970 rural residents are benefitting in Year One. 

SHC's Impact grant is proceeding as expected. Medical service providers requested shifting to a 60-day model for payments. This payment request represents the operating expenses for 60 days, covering May and June 2025 including:
Personnel expenses for medical providers and project staff (Project Director, Healthcare Navigator LPN, OB/GYN, Primary Care Physician, Primary Care Nurse Practitioner, Family / Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner, Lead Peer Recovery Specialist, Community Health Worker / Peer Recovery Specialist, Pharmacist, Interpreter, Transportation / Specialty Referral Director, Transportation Coordinator, Billing Coordinator, Program Intake Enrollment Coordinator.)
Transportation expenses for connecting clients with services.
Supplies to meet Naloxone, Suboxone, and Recovery Community supply needs.
Contractual for the required Data Coordinator position and reserved daycare spaces for youth and families served.
Other expenses related to MOUD training for healthcare students, Outreach materials, Transportation Insurance, and Emergency Transitional Housing for individuals navigating SUD treatment and recovery.

Payment Justification for Subaccounts 24T91HP25784, 24T91HP25781, 24T91HP25780, 24T91HP53248 (Teaching Health Center Program):

The requested funds are necessary to support approved activities under our HRSA Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education (THCGME) award. These funds will be used to cover the following:

Salaries and fringe benefits for primary care medical residents

Faculty and preceptor compensation for supervising community-based training

Administrative support staff involved in managing the THC program

Training-related costs such as medical liability insurance, educational materials and rotations

These expenditures are directly aligned with the purpose of the THCGME award—to expand community-based primary care training and strengthen the pipeline of providers in underserved areas. All costs are consistent with our approved budget and allowable under 45 CFR Part 75 and HRSA’s award terms.

recipient_justification: We are requesting payment of $96,352 for the period 4/1/25 - 4/15/25.  The requested funds will be allocated for Personnel costs only.  This drawdown utilizes funds to provide comprehensive primary care services delivered to underserved and vulnerable populations in the community served by SJCH FQHC.  Medical Provider Personnel costs only are included in this drawdown, authorized under Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act.  The funds fall under the Health Center Program, which is a federal initiative managed by the Bureau of Primary Health Care (BPHC) within the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA). The program is funded through a combination of discretionary funding appropriated by Congress and mandatory funding from the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF). The foundation of the Health Center Program supports the core mission of this innovative and successful model of primary care. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the NOA.

recipient_justification: We are requesting payment of $97,481 for the period 4/1/25 - 4/15/25.  The requested funds will be allocated for Personnel costs only.  This drawdown utilizes funds to provide comprehensive primary care services delivered to underserved and vulnerable populations in the community served by SJCH FQHC.  Medical Provider Personnel costs only are included in this drawdown, authorized under Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act.  The funds fall under the Health Center Program, which is a federal initiative managed by the Bureau of Primary Health Care (BPHC) within the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA). The program is funded through a combination of discretionary funding appropriated by Congress and mandatory funding from the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF). The foundation of the Health Center Program supports the core mission of this innovative and successful model of primary care. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the NOA.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Grant Identification Information: 00766
•	Award Number: 4 T91HP25795‐12‐01
•	Federal Award Project Title: Affordable Care Act Teaching Health Center (THC) Graduate Medical Education (GME) Payment Program
•	FAIN: T9125795
•	Period of Performance Start/End Date: 07/01/2024 – 06/30/2026
•	Drawdown Amount Requested: $90,510.84
•	Time Period Covered: March 1, 2025 – March 31, 2025
Purpose: This drawdown request in the amount of $90,510.84 supports the continued operation of our residency program under the Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education Payment Program. The funds were used to cover critical costs associated with graduate medical education, including resident salaries, faculty support, and training-related expenses, all contributing to a high-quality clinical learning environment in a community-based setting.  
Alignment with Government Goals: This funding aligns with the federal goal of expanding access to access to care, increasing the number of skilled professionals, promoting community-based training, encouraging long-term commitment, providing care in underserved populations, and improving health outcomes. 
Justification for Amount: The drawdown amount of $90,510.84 reflects actual, eligible costs incurred during the current reporting period. These costs include
•	Resident salary and fringe benefits
•	Faculty time and supervision
•	Educational resources and administrative support
All expenses are allowable under the TCH GME program budget and are compliant with 2 CFR Part 200 (Uniform Guidance)
All expenditures have been reviewed and approved by the organization’s fiscal team

The funding supports medical outreach and navigation services for unhoused residents in the Sacramento area. Salaries cover medical support staff who assist individuals experiencing homelessness in accessing care. This funding ensures continuity of care, staff retention, and access to essential resources that promote health equity in underserved communities.

recipient_justification: Priority Health Care invests HRSA funds mainly in salaries and benefits for medical staff. These professionals deliver hands-on care to people in the community, focusing on the treatment and control of chronic illnesses like high blood pressure and diabetes. The team also teaches patients about healthy habits and how to manage their medications.   The pediatric staff offers regular checkups for infants and teens. During these visits, they track growth and watch for important developmental markers. This helps families stay informed about their child’s health and progress. Regular assessments also let the team spot concerns early and recommend helpful steps. Parents can feel confident knowing their child’s development receives close attention at each stage.  Mental health support is available as well, with staff providing psychiatric care and talk therapy to address mental health issues and substance use disorders.

recipient_justification:
Grant Identification Information: 00763
•	Award Number: 6 T91HP24224-13-02
•	Federal Award Project Title: Affordable Care Act Teaching Health Center (THC) Graduate Medical Education (GME) Payment Program
•	FAIN: T9124224
•	Period of Performance Start/End Date: 07/01/2024 – 06/30/2026
•	Time Period Covered: March 1, 2025 – March 31, 2025
Purpose: This drawdown request in the amount of $86,383.25 supports costs associated with training a dental resident through our accredited Teaching Health Center GME program. The funds cover dental residency salary, fringe benefits, and program-related expenses that contribute to the delivery of community-based oral healthcare education in underserved populations.
Alignment with Government Goals: This funding aligns with the federal goal of expanding access to access to care and increasing the number of skilled professionals, promoting community-based training, encouraging long-term commitment, providing care in underserved populations, and improving health outcomes. 
Justification for Amount: The drawdown amount of $86,383.25 represents allowable, allocable, and reasonable expenses incurred during the specified period:
•	Resident salary and fringe benefits
•	Faculty time and supervision
•	Educational resources and administrative support
All costs are compliant with 2 CFR Part 200 and consistent with the approved TCH GME program budget.
All expenditures have been reviewed and approved by the organization’s fiscal team
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
This payment request supports March 2025 expenditures under the RCORP Impact grant, in alignment with the approved workplan to expand behavioral health access and reduce substance use in rural Georgia.

Personnel & Fringe: Covers salaries and fringe benefits for staff implementing RCORP initiatives, including care coordination, program oversight, and administrative support.

Travel: Includes local travel for the Project Director and costs for travel, lodging, and meals to attend the required RCORP national meeting in Washington, DC.

Supplies: Includes office supplies and materials used for program operations and community collaborative outreach.

Contractual (Share Health/HOPE Coordinator): 

Data collection and coordination, program evaluation, technical assistance, and sustainability planning. coordinated by Share Health Southeast Georgia.

Contract with OATH for HOPE Coordinator - to lead efforts to expand access to behavioral health services for homeless and high-risk populations, as outlined in the grant’s approved scope of work.

Other:  Includes costs for electronic health record (Carelogic) and Microsoft 365 licenses, mobile phone service and internet access for field-based staff; Training and curriculum costs for evidence-based programs: A New Direction, Moving On, and Complete Living in Balance; Basic office furnishings to implement the MAT program in Brantley County; and costs associated with onboarding new employees, including background checks and fingerprinting

Indirect Costs:   Calculated at 10% of eligible direct costs to support overall program administration and ensure compliance with grant requirements.

All expenditures occurred in March 2025 and directly support the RCORP Impact program's mission to reduce substance use disparities and improve behavioral health access in rural, underserved communities.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Grant Expense Justification for Teaching Health Center Residency Program
Purpose of Drawdown:
This drawdown request utilizes grant funds awarded to support the operation and infrastructure of the Teaching Health Center Residency Program. The funds are applied to cover direct personnel expenses as well as necessary administrative and financial oversight required to sustain program compliance and effectiveness.
________________________________________
Detailed Breakdown of Expenses:
1. Resident Salaries and Educational Support
•	Residents (12 Total) – $38,176.92
Supports the salaries/stipends of resident physicians actively engaged in the program, ensuring continuity in patient care and hands-on medical training.
•	In-House Resident Preceptors- $10,076.97
Supports salaries of providers that serve as a preceptor the Residents at many of our locations. Provide training to residents and provides direction in physician practicing. 
2. Residency Program Administration
•	Resident Program Director – $12,500.00
Covers compensation for the physician leading the program, responsible for ensuring curriculum compliance, clinical supervision, and accreditation standards.
•	Resident Coordinator – $2,307.70
Provides administrative support necessary for scheduling, evaluations, onboarding, and general residency operations.
•	Employer FICA - $5,312.01	
Justifies Employer FICA for payroll costs and compliance with all tax reporting.
3. Finance and Administrative Support
•	Finance Department Costs–$2,864.20 
Justifies time and resources allocated by finance personnel in managing budget tracking, grant reporting, reimbursement processing, and fiscal oversight specific to the residency program.
•	Administrative Oversight / Compliance Monitoring –$3,512.20
Includes costs associated with executive review, human resources support and ensuring compliance with HRSA grant requirements and institutional policies.

4.	Total Cost Justification and Grant Drawdown Request: $74,750
________________________________________
Conclusion:
This drawdown represents a justifiable and compliant use of grant funds as outlined in the Teaching Health Center GME program requirements. It covers the essential salaries of clinical and administrative staff directly involved in resident education, while also recognizing the necessary financial and operational infrastructure that ensures the program’s success and sustainability.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Payment Justification Summary for Ryan White Part C EIS Funds (March 2025):

The March 2025 allocation of Ryan White Part C EIS funds was strategically utilized to advance the program’s mission of reducing HIV disparities in the South and Central Bronx, with a focus on the high-need communities and zip codes specified in the NOFO. These funds supported both Personnel Services (PS) and Other Than Personnel Services (OTPS), ensuring the delivery of comprehensive, equitable care while adhering to federal guidelines and the Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) Initiative’s priorities.

Personnel Services (PS) were critical to maintaining a skilled workforce dedicated to direct service delivery and program operations. Clinical staff, including infectious disease specialists, provided essential HIV care such as antiretroviral therapy (ART) management, viral load monitoring, and telehealth consultations for patients facing mobility or transportation challenges. Outreach workers and linkage-to-care coordinators conducted community-based testing initiatives in neighborhoods like Hunts Point-Morrisania and Crotona-Tremont, ensuring timely diagnosis and connection to care for marginalized populations, including Black and Latinx communities, and people who inject drugs. Case managers addressed social determinants of health by securing housing resources, food assistance, and benefits enrollment for vulnerable patients, while mental health counselors offered trauma-informed support in collaboration with local organizations. Administrative personnel ensured compliance with HRSA reporting requirements, tracked outcomes, and coordinated logistics, maintaining the program’s operational integrity.

Other Than Personnel Services (OTPS) covered the operational and programmatic expenses necessary to sustain and enhance service delivery. Rapid HIV testing kits, viral load lab services, and ART to support early diagnosis and treatment initiation. Transportation assistance, including MetroCards, reduced barriers to clinic attendance for residents of transit-limited areas like Fordham-Bronx Park. Partnerships with community-based organizations such as BronxWorks and Urban Health Plan expanded access to housing support, food pantries, and harm reduction services, amplifying the program’s reach. Competency training for staff ensured services were delivered in a linguistically and culturally responsive manner to diverse populations, including those with limited English proficiency.

The synergy between PS and OTPS was pivotal to the program’s success. For example, outreach workers (PS) utilized public transportation – staff travel (OTPS) to engage hard-to-reach populations, while case managers (PS) leveraged transportation MetroCard (OTPS) to retain patients in care. Together, these investments ensured continuity of services, strengthened patient-provider relationships, and advanced measurable outcomes such as timely linkage-to-care and improved retention rates.

All expenditures adhered strictly to Ryan White Part C EIS guidelines (CFDA 93.918) and the NOFO’s scope of work. PS costs were validated through timesheets and role-specific job descriptions, while OTPS expenses were documented via invoices, service agreements, and procurement records. These investments not only complied with federal requirements but also reinforced the program’s commitment to health equity, community collaboration, and sustainable care models in one of the nation’s most underserved regions.

recipient_justification:
"grant funds were utilized to support essential services and operations critical to achieving the goals outlined in the grant requirements. These funds were primarily allocated to maintain and operate a fully functional primary care clinic that provides comprehensive healthcare services to enrolled patients, particularly those experiencing homelessness or other barriers to accessing medical care.
The funding facilitated the provision of vital medical care and resources, ensuring that patients receive quality treatment and preventive care tailored to their needs. It supported the recruitment and retention of qualified medical practitioners and healthcare professionals, enabling the clinic to deliver consistent, high-quality services to the community. Additionally, the funds were directed toward sustaining community public health initiatives aimed at addressing the social determinants of health, improving outreach efforts, and fostering partnerships with other organizations to enhance care delivery."

	$72,260
  Phone and Internet service costs.
