Software. ARHP is requesting federal funding for $23,200/year for annual subscriptions, including $5,500/year for Board Effect for membership communications, $15,000/year for Good Grid for project tracking and access to SDOH assistance programs, $500/year for staff computer programming software, and $2,200/year for the website platform.  	$23,200
Diabetes Education Empowerment Program (DEEP) Training. ARHP requests federal funding for $21,300/year for Year II to train Diabetes Education Empowerment Program (DEEP) trainers in partnership with the Arkansas Foundation for Medical Care (AFMC). AFMC will train up to 22 facilities/locations. DEEP train-the-trainer sessions consist of six one-hour training sessions. 	$21,300
Community Health Worker Training. In Year II, ARHP will provide Community Health Worker Training to 32 healthcare workers in healthcare organizations throughout the services area. The training/certification costs are $1,500 per CHW. The project will target current frontline staff members in hospital and clinics.	$48,000
Association Dues. ARHP requests $3,410 for Year II to cover the costs of membership dues for ARHP staff for the following organizations:
•	National Rural Health Association (NRHA):   $1,225/annual dues
•	National Cooperative of Health Networks (NCHN):    $2,035/annual dues
•	Arkansas Community Health Worker Association (ARCHWA):  $150/annual dues	$3,410
Vehicle Insurance /Maintenance. ARHP requests $4,200 in Year II to cover the ARHP van vehicle insurance ($3,200) and miscellaneous repairs/maintenance ($1,000) for the Good Food Rx van that delivers food to senior patients.	$4,200
Data Reporting (Google Workspace Plan). ARHP requests $5,760 in Year II for 32 project staff (including 20 new positions starting in September 2024) for the email and reporting platform through Google Workspace ($15/month x 32 personnel x 12 months = $5,760 in Year II.	$5,760
Rural Health Column (Healthcare Journal of Arkansas). ARHP will write a rural healthcare column for the Healthcare Journal of Arkansas, which will be distributed throughout Arkansas. The column will highlight ARHP program initiatives and rural healthcare issues, specifically in the Arkansas Delta Region. ARHP is requesting $9,000 to cover the costs of publishing the bi-monthly articles and promoting CHW services in the publication, which will be distributed to all healthcare organizations throughout Arkansas.	$9,000
Good Food Rx Research Data Report. ARHP requests $20,000 for consulting to assist with data and evaluation of the Good Food Rx program in Helena, Arkansas. By June 2025, Well Fed will provide a full report of the Good Food Rx pilot project in Phillips County to assist ARHP with efforts to increase financial support for the food pharmacy to serve patients in Arkansas Delta chronic care management programs at participating clinics. ARHP will provide this entire report to HRSA FORHP.	$20,000
Resource Directory Software Platform. ARHP will be using Batch GEO, an interactive online mapping platform. This platform enables ARHP to upload and change resource data as needed to ensure accurate information for ARHP members, partners, and community members throughout the Delta Region. It allows ARHP to change the mapping of resources as needed. The cost is $2,000 per year for 20 users.	$2,000

recipient_justification: The purpose of this grant is to support the provision of cancer screening services for medically underserved populations in the rural regions of Northern Arizona. As part of our Well Woman program, this initiative primarily focuses on increasing access to breast and cervical cancer screenings. Grant funds will be used to support personnel costs, specifically covering salaries and wages for one full-time equivalent (1 FTE) staff member dedicated to delivering these critical services. This includes travel to remote and hard-to-reach areas to ensure that individuals who might otherwise lack access to care receive necessary screenings. In addition to direct services, the program also provides community outreach, education, and awareness efforts aimed at promoting early detection and improving health outcomes in this targeted population.

recipient_justification: NNOHA’s grant award is for providing training and technical assistance (TTA) on strategies to improve access to oral health services. TTA topics include chronic disease management, UDS Sealant Measure, and innovative strategies to deliver oral health care. The funds will be used to cover expenses already incurred for direct salaries of staff and consultant expenses in the provision of TTA to health centers across the country. Additionally, the funds will be used to cover travel and venue expenses for in-person training events conducted in March. The funds will also cover general administrative expenses already incurred, such as rent, website maintenance, supplies, printing, and telephone use. These costs are for the time period of March 1 to March 31, 2025, which is based on the grant award activities in NNOHA’s grant project work plan. These funds are necessary to support the staffing structure and administrative expenses required to provide TTA under this grant program.

recipient_justification:
This request includes additional reimbursement for expenses already paid out on behalf of the project for personnel, fringes, supplies, travel, participant/trainee support costs, and indirect.  Those cost include but are not limited to:

Personnel	Year III
(Revised)
Project Director. Cecilia Trotter will dedicate .40 fte to this project and provide oversight and management, including required reporting, data collection, and assistance coordinating grant-related activities. Ms. Trotter will directly support the Healthcare Workforce Recruiter and all project staff. ($72,000/annual salary @ .40fte = $28,800/yr for Year III)  Cecilia is .75fte on DOL Worc 3 Pop Extension through July  31, 2025. 	$28,800
Co-Project Director/Healthcare Workforce Recruiter.  Carol Anne Rowland (formerly Career Counselor) will dedicate .70fte to this project and assist with providing oversight and management as needed and job placement services for students leading up to and after graduation, including coordinating job placement with network partners and other entities, conducting student workshops in interviewing and resume writing, and assisting with student follow-up after completion of the grant.  ($48,000 annually @ 70%  = $33,600 annually)                                          		$33,600
Executive Assistant. Camille Watson will dedicate .10fte to this project, providing support to the leadership team. ($65,000 annually @ 10%  = $6,500 annually)	$6,500
Director of Human Resources & Contractual Services	0
Associate Director, Arkansas Rural Health Academy. Amanda Kuttenkuler (formerly Senior Programs Director). will dedicate .15fte to this project to provide assistance with colleges and establish formal, written agreements with partners as needed.   ($80,000 annually @ 15%  = $12,000 annually)   Concern listing her here since she will be teaching under the ARHA. 	$12,000
Chief Operations Officer. Lynn Hawkins will dedicate .10fte to this position to support all project staff and provide coordination with project stakeholders.  ($120,000 annually @ 10% = $12,000 annually)	$12,000
Grants Management. TBD.  This position will provide assistance to the full ARHP leadership team and Project Directors to ensure all reporting and compliance guidance is adequately met @ $24,840 annually.	$24,840
Website Designer. Bradley Lail will dedicate time to this project for website development and maintenance.  This position will allow the ARHP website to continue to be updated with resources and communication at $12,000 annually.	$12,000
Creative Manager. Matt Jones will dedicate .10fte to this project for the development of brochures and communication materials.  ($70,000 annually @ 10% = $70,000 annually)	$7,000
Total Personnel	$136,740
Fringe Benefits 	Year III
(Revised)
Project Director. Cecilia Trotter.  ARHP is requesting federal funding in the amount of $8,640/year for this position.   Fringe benefits are calculated @ 0.40 fte ($28,800 @ 30% fringe = $8,640)	$8,640
Co-Project Director/Healthcare Workforce Recruiter.  Carol Anne Rowland. ARHP is requesting federal funding in the amount of $10,080 for this position calculated @ .30fte ($33,600 @ 30% fringe = $10,080)	$10,080
Executive Assistant. Camille Watson.  ARHP is requesting federal funding in the amount of $1,950/year for this position.  Fringe benefits are calculated at @ 0.15 fte ($6,500 @ 30% fringe = $1,950)	$1,950
Director of Human Resources & Contractual Services.	0
Associate Director, Arkansas Rural Health Academy. Amanda Kuttenkuler. ARHP is requesting federal funding in the amount of $3,600/year for this position.   Fringe benefits are calculated @ 0.15 fte ($12,000 @ 30% fringe = $3,600)	$3,600
Chief Operations Officer. Lynn Hawkins will dedicate .10fte to this position to support all project staff and provide coordination with project stakeholders.  ($12,000 annually @ 30% fringe = $3,600 annually)	$3,600
Creative Manager. Matt Jones ARHP is requesting federal funding in the amount of $1,950/year for this position.  Fringe benefits are calculated at @ 0.10 fte ($7,000 @ 30% fringe = $2,100)	$2,100
Total Fringe	$29,970
Supplies	Year III
(Revised)
Publication Costs. ARHP is requesting federal funding in the amount of $1,000 per year in Year I-IV to develop and print rack cards and educational booklets highlighting the educational opportunities will be distributed via the workforce mobile unit to students in local high schools and colleges, workforce offices, and clinics and hospitals in the service area.	$1,000
Internet, Phone, Subscription Cost. ARHP is requesting Internet, Phone, and Subscription costs to support 2 staff members at $100 per month for telephone, $75 per month for internet, and $50 per month for subscriptions (including but not limited to adobe, Microsoft office, computer virus protection, zoom, GoToMeeting, LogMeIn, etc.). ($225 x 2 staff = $450 x 12 months = $5,400 annually).	$5,400
Total Supplies	$6,400
Travel	Year III
(Revised)
Staff. $6,150/ Year I-IV. Project staff will travel to schools, hospitals, high school career fairs, and colleges throughout the duration of the project. ARHP is requesting travel funding in the amount of $6,150/year. Travel is estimated at 876/miles per month for all staff. (876 miles/month x 12 months x $.585/mile= $6,150/year).	$6,150
Total Travel	$6,150
Program and Administrative Costs Sub-Total	Year III
(Revised)
Participant/Trainee Support Costs (should equal 60% of total budget)	
Participant/Trainee Support	Year III
(Revised)
Laptops. ARHP is requesting federal funds in the amount of $2,274 in Year III for laptops for participating students in the program.  Laptop costs are calculated at $568.50 per laptop x 4 laptops = $2,274. 	2,274
Tuition/Fees.  ARHP is requesting to allocate $431,970 towards participant tuition and fees for Year III. ARHP will closely track the number and type of students trained, along with support provided. University of Arkansas Grantham recently increased costs per term from $2,070 per term to $2,130 per term in May of 2024. Students affected by the costs increase are also reflected. Current and newly enrolled participant costs are reflected below: 
•	7 students (Associate Degree) @19.5 terms x 2070 per term = $40,365
•	24 students (Associate Degree) @ 141 terms x 2130 per term = $300,330
•	4 students (Bachelor’s Degree) @ 23 terms x 2070 per term = $47,610
•	1 student (Bachelor’s Degree) @ 6 terms x 2130 per term = $12,780
•	8 students (Certification) @ 14.5 terms x 2130 per term = $30,885	431,970
Apprenticeships. 	0
Textbooks and Resources. ARHP is requesting funds in the amount of $18,180 to support textbooks and certification costs for students in Year III. ARHP will allocate $14,000 to provide participants textbooks (70 textbooks @ $200 per book= $14,000). Certification support costs include exam preparation materials and exam purchase. Costs for certification exam support are calculated at $4,180 (11 exams @ $300 per exam = $3,300) (11 exam preparation books @ $80 per book = $880). 
•	70 textbooks @ $200 per book = $14,000
•	11 additional certification exams @$300 per exam = $3,300
11 exam preparation books @ $80 per book = $880	18,180
Participant/Trainee Support Cost Sub-Total	$452,424[1]

Direct Costs Total	$631,684
Indirect Costs	Year III
(Revised)
Indirect Costs Rate: Requested of 8% ($40,740/year)	$49,339
Indirect Cost Total	$49,339
Total Costs (Direct Costs Total + Indirect Costs Total)	$681,023

recipient_justification: In May 2025, HRSA MAT Access funds supported critical recovery housing and wraparound services for individuals with substance use disorders, many of whom were unsheltered. Thirty-four recovery beds were maintained across Shelby, Lincolnton, and Mt. Airy, providing safe, sober housing paired with peer support, MAT access, and care navigation.  Peer Support Specialists and staff delivered daily recovery support and outreach. Funds also supported mobile phone access for clients, community awareness through WHKY radio, data evaluation via NC State, and workspace for five PSS staff, strengthening our community-based care model.

recipient_justification:
Payroll Expense Narrative – March 2025
MarillacHealth requested reimbursement for payroll expenses related to increased Mental Health Care and Substance Use Disorder Services supported by HRSA Grant Award No. 1 H8NCS53990-01-00, NOA awarded on September 18, 2024. The following payroll expenses reflect salaries and benefits paid to eligible staff for the service period.

Payroll Period Ending March 1, 2025:
Payroll expenses for this period totaled $16,765.12. These costs include proportional salary and benefits for staff such as designated Nurse Practitioners, Licensed Professional Counselors, Medical Assistants, and the Chief Medical Officer. All expenses align with the approved scope and allocation as outlined in the HRSA grant award to expand behavioral health services at our two school-based health centers and Montrose clinic.

Payroll Period Ending March 15, 2025:
Payroll expenses for this period totaled $16,809.04. These costs include proportional salary and benefits for staff such as designated Nurse Practitioners, Licensed Professional Counselors, Medical Assistants, and the Chief Medical Officer. All expenses align with the approved scope and allocation as outlined in the HRSA grant award to expand behavioral health care at our two school-based health centers and Montrose Clinic.

Payroll Period Ending March 29, 2025:
Payroll expenses for this period totaled $16,808.43. These costs include proportional salary and benefits for staff such as designated Nurse Practitioners, Licensed Professional Counselors, Medical Assistants, and the Chief Medical Officer. All expenses align with the approved scope and allocation as outlined in the HRSA grant award to expand behavioral health services at our two school-based health centers and Montrose Clinic.

Total amount requested for the month of March 2025: $50,382.59.

recipient_justification: The HRSA Grant is entitled RCORP-Impact and is to provide coordinated, integrated, and sustainable treatment and recovery services for people with substance use disorders, including opioid use disorders, in rural areas.  The grant enables us to create or expand services in a six county region in NE Wisconsin.  All of the funds in this request were part of the budget approved in March, and have been used for their intended purpose.  The itemized detail: Personnel:  April staff wages to manage the grant - $6,757; Third month of salary for the therapist in the Shawano Outpatient Clinic Start-Up - $6,000; Wages for the Care Coordinator/Peer Support Specialist in the Shawano Recovery House - $4,000.  Fringe Benefits: $1,188 for grant management staff and $799 for Care Coordinator/Peer Support for April.  Travel: Mandatory Attendance at March HRSA RSV Conference in DC in March for 2 staff - $3,546.17.  Contractual:  Emergency Social Detox beds in Manitowoc (2 beds, 30 days, $195/day) - $11,700; Impact Wisconsin Recovery House Care Coordinator - $5,000 for April;  Impact Wisconsin room and board for 3 beds at $65/day - $5,850.  Other:  Shawano Outpatient Clinic Start-Up rent - $1,500.  Indirect costs for April - $3,397.  Total of $49,737.17.

recipient_justification: This award is for developing and delivering training and technical assistance that supports health centers in improving the health of individuals and communities in Hawaii. Funds will be used to pay for costs associated with carrying out workplan activities including staff salaries, supplies, consultants, training, and operations. Funds are necessary to support staff and infrastructure needed to carry out workplan activities aimed at increasing access to comprehensive high-quality primary health care services; recruiting and retaining a strong health care workforce; preparing for, responding to, and recovering from emergent health events; implementing value-based care delivery and ensuring financial sustainability; and accelerating data-informed improvements to operations, clinical quality, and care coordination. This includes improving maternal health outcomes through assessments and partnerships and enhancing health center capacity to prevent and respond to Intimate Partner Violence.

recipient_justification: ACHC was awarded two year grant funding ($600,000 per year) to expand services to Behavioral Health (BH) and Substance Use Disorder patients in SW Iowa.  ACHC was recently approved by the state of Iowa to provide treatment to SUD patients and has long been providing quality BH services.  There is a very high need in our area; we have hired the 6.95 FTE approved in the grant application and our providers are almost fully booked daily.  ACHC used non-federal funds to renovate space in our building and relocate administrative staff.  This will allow us to increase the level of integration between primary care and SUD/BH, facilitating a warm hand-off when a patient screens positive for SUD/BH disorders.  By increasing the patient flow we are increasing operating efficiency and provider productivity.  Year 2 of the grant funding begins 9/01/2025; all funding in the year two grant will go to the staff salaries.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
The funded project supports the agency in several activities that improve the quality of our treatment and outcomes for youth in our communities, including 1. Funding evidence-based prevention work in schools aimed at reducing tobacco use/vaping and suicide risk in teens; 2. Offering training in mental health first aid that otherwise we would not be able to afford and 3. Helping us offer modest stipends to students in social work programs to intern with our staff and clients.  This also allows us to have our professional staff supervise the interns in cooperation with our local public universities.

This month, this grant paid for staff salaries for youth prevention workers, peer mental health specialists, and therapists’ time who are actively supervising interns.  It also paid the salary of the grant coordinator, who is a clinician, to ensure activities are carried out and based on best practices.

The agency is a community mental health agency that offers safety-net care for all who come to us. Our region of Maine has some of the highest rates of substance use, major depression, and suicide - notably for youth.  If we did not have these funds, we could not do these important activities that the grant supports.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
•	Award Number: 6 T91HP53233‐01‐02
•	Federal Award Project Title: Teaching Health Center (THC) Graduate Medical Education (GME) Payment Program
•	FAIN: T9153233
•	Period of Performance Start/End Date: 07/01/2024 – 06/30/2026
•	Drawdown Amount Requested: $45,092.99
•	Time Period Covered: March 1, 2025 – March 31, 2025
Purpose: This drawdown request in the amount of $45,092.99 supports the continued operation of our residency program under the Teaching Health Center Graduate Medical Education Payment Program. The funds were used to cover critical costs associated with graduate medical education, including resident salaries, faculty support, and training-related expenses, all contributing to a high-quality clinical learning environment in a community-based setting.  
Alignment with Government Goals: This funding aligns with the federal goal of expanding access to access to care and increasing the number of skilled professionals, promoting community-based training, encouraging long-term commitment, providing care in underserved populations, and improving health outcomes. 
Justification for Amount: The drawdown amount of $45,092.99 reflects actual, eligible costs incurred during the current reporting period. These costs include
•	Resident salary and fringe benefits
•	Faculty time and supervision
•	Educational resources and administrative support
All expenses are allowable under the TCH GME program budget and are compliant with 2 CFR Part 200 (Uniform Guidance)
All expenditures have been reviewed and approved by the organization’s fiscal team
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Family Voices Colorado
Family to Family Health Information Centers (F2F HIC)
Payment Request 5/5/2025 Award FAIN#H8445665, Award Date 4/3/2024

The Family-to-Family Health Information Center project at Family Voices Colorado (FVCO) provides comprehensive, knowledgeable services that educate, equip, and empower Colorado’s families of CYSHCN (Children and Youth with Special Health Care Needs), and the multidisciplinary professionals who serve them. This payment request for $44,279.09 from Year 3 of the grant includes:
Personnel $25,026.53:
Salaries $22,886.63 for Project Director, Blakely, $1,104.99; Family Navigator Bowser, $13,820.63, and two Outreach Family Navigators $7,961.01; and related Unemployment $389.07 and Social Security/Medicare $1,750.83.

Travel $1,676.73: Flights and Lodging for two staff family navigators to attend the annual Family Voices meeting in Washington D.C to confer with other F2F HIC grantees.

Supplies/Printing $75.83: a wagon to transport Transition Wheel supplies to School districts, CCB or providers' offices.

Professional Fees: Subcontractors $17,500:
-El Grupo Vida $5,000 (El Grupo Visa is a network of Hispanic/Latino parents formed to provide mutual support for people with disabilities or special needs).
-Janet Taylor, Evaluator Consultant, $2,500 for administering surveys after a family calls the Family Voices support line with questions such as “What services did the family need, follow-up questions, were your questions answered? Are you satisfied with the services”; interpret survey answers, and report results.
-Other subcontractors: Parent 2 Parent, $5,000; and Show and Tell $5,000 for Family Navigation led organizations in Colorado for their work in the Family 2 Family Coalition based on their support.

Total $44,279.09
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: Funds were utilized for reimbursement of payments for the Azara DRVS program as well as supporting server costs.   Azara DRVS directly supports the goals of the UDS program by providing FQHCs with the tools to monitor, analyze, and improve performance on UDS clinical quality measures throughout the year, as well as compilation of overall patient information including demographics. By enabling real-time tracking, patient-level drill-downs, and data validation, Azara helps health centers identify care gaps, implement targeted interventions, and demonstrate measurable improvements in key metrics such as diabetes control, hypertension, cancer screenings, and preventive care. This enhances the health center’s ability to submit accurate, timely UDS data that reflects quality improvement efforts.

recipient_justification: We collaborate with NextGen Healthcare in the process of implementing the reporting tool for UDS+. Our IT and Compliance Directors have dedicated many hours to this effort. To capture accurate demographic data for our patients, we utilize a web-based solution, Phreesia, for patient intake. Phreesia’s Digital Check-In platform allows patients to enter their information directly, which interfaces seamlessly with our Electronic Health Record (EHR) system, NextGen. Additionally, we utilize i2i, a reporting platform, to conduct audits to ensure the information integrated from Phreesia is accurate. We have also performed audits on our diabetic patients, for unknown A1C values for 2024 and YTD 2025. These audits identify which patients are due for appointments. We actively review our diabetic coding practices to ensure we are specific. To support the management of our diabetic patients, we have two Diabetes Educators on staff; their visits are non-billable and free to all patients.

Time period: March1-31, 2025

Personnel and Fringe Benefit Costs – 

Personnel and fringe benefit costs are essential to implementing and sustaining the Safe Babies Court Team (SBCT) model in Colorado. Illuminate Colorado is responsible for launching and supporting SBCT implementation across four established sites and securing the required fifth site to meet statewide program objectives. To achieve this, dedicated staff are necessary to provide direct support to each site, including site coordination, fidelity monitoring, technical assistance, and facilitation of collaborative cross-system partnerships.

In addition to local site implementation, funding supports critical state-level coordination to ensure alignment with national SBCT standards, consistent quality assurance, and robust interagency collaboration. Staff funded under this budget provide technical assistance and consultation to site-based stakeholders, participate in strategic planning, and facilitate the Active Community Team and State Advisory Board.

To ensure the continuity and integrity of programmatic delivery and administration, supportive staff were leveraged across the organization. This includes personnel in data and evaluation to track outcomes and support continuous improvement, communications staff to manage stakeholder engagement and dissemination efforts, education team members to develop and deliver SBCT training content, policy staff to align the SBCT model with statewide systems-change initiatives, and finance and operations staff to manage budgeting, compliance, and reporting responsibilities.

The allocation of personnel and fringe benefit costs reflects a comprehensive and integrated approach to implementing the Safe Babies Court Team model with fidelity, while maintaining accountability, sustainability, and statewide coordination.

Travel - 

Travel is a necessary and allowable cost to support the implementation, evaluation, and statewide coordination of the Safe Babies Court Team (SBCT) model across Colorado. As this project involves active engagement with multiple judicial districts and community partners, in-person travel is required to establish and support site-level implementation, provide technical assistance, facilitate cross-agency collaboration, and conduct fidelity and quality assurance activities.

Travel costs will cover mileage, lodging, per diem, and other allowable expenses for staff and contractors traveling to SBCT sites—including four currently active sites and a fifth site in development. Site visits are critical for building relationships, conducting training and coaching, facilitating collaborative team meetings, and ensuring alignment with SBCT core components.

Additionally, travel supports participation in statewide meetings, learning communities, and evaluation planning sessions, including visits to partner organizations such as the Kempe Center, court systems, and child welfare agencies. Participation in national-level peer learning opportunities and convenings ensures Colorado’s implementation remains aligned with best practices and emerging evidence from the broader SBCT community.

Overall, travel supports the effectiveness, responsiveness, and sustainability of the SBCT model across diverse geographic regions in Colorado and contributes to stronger outcomes for infants, toddlers, and families served by the program.

________________________________________
Comprehensive Breakdown of Expenses for HRSA Community Health Worker 
(CHW 2025) Program – April 2025
To facilitate the timely and accurate processing of the payment request for the HRSA-funded CHW Program, please find below a detailed breakdown of each line item totaling $38,938.43, including item descriptions, services rendered, associated personnel, and corresponding costs. All expenses align with the programmatic goals and budgeted categories approved under HRSA guidelines.
________________________________________
I. Personnel Expenses
These salary payments reflect direct labor associated with program execution, recruitment, reporting, and administration. Each individual’s role contributes to successful delivery and compliance of the CHW 2025 program.

Staff Member	Title/Role	Description of Services	Amount

Dorothy E. Forde	Principal Investigator	Oversees program implementation, ensures HRSA compliance, supervises academic integrity and outcomes.	$1,395.83

Earl S. Henry	Co-Principal Investigator	Supports curriculum development, training standards, and evaluation metrics.	$1,159.19

Denise W. Finley	Program Manager	Manages daily operations, coordinates activities across program units, ensures goal alignment and timeliness.	$2,125.21

Lenova Ramella	Project Assistant	Provides logistical and clerical support; assists with documentation and coordination of program events.	$750.00

Robyn T. Lang	Budget Specialist	Processes financial transactions, monitors budget allocations, ensures accurate reporting to HRSA.	$500.00

Michelle A. Ramey	Project Specialist, Recruitment Manager & Report Coordinator	Manages project deliverables and report submissions; supports strategic recruitment planning.	$1,250.00

Monique Morales-Mason	Report Coordinator & Recruiter	Compiles program data for reporting; actively engages in community outreach and student recruitment.	$750.00

Kennee Joy Moore	Recruiter	Participates in outreach activities to recruit CHW trainees.	$857.14

Ivy J. Starks	Recruiter	Supports targeted recruitment efforts.	$857.14

Carlos D. Cole	Recruiter	Conducts outreach and community presentations to attract potential CHWs.	$857.14

Lornette Stokes	Recruiter	Engages with local organizations and residents to support recruitment strategies.	$857.14

Subtotal – Salaries: $11,468.79
________________________________________
II. Program Operations & Outreach
These items support the operational and outreach efforts necessary to recruit, engage, and train participants in the CHW program.

Item/Service	Description	Amount

Recruitment Billboards	Paid advertisement for the HRSA CHW 2025 program placed in high-traffic areas to raise awareness and drive enrollment among target populations.	$12,857.00

Apprenticeship Stipend – Amani McCray	Apprentice support payment as required by the grant to promote retention by reducing financial barriers for trainees.	$625.00

Printing – CHW Workbooks (90 units)	Professionally printed training materials provided to CHW trainees for use during the upcoming Summer 2025 program.	$12,497.64

Subtotal – Outreach & Operations: $25,979.64
________________________________________
III. Grand Total

Category	Total
Salaries	$11,468.79
Outreach & Operations	$25,979.64
Total Request	$38,938.43
________________________________________
Summary Justification
This payment request includes necessary personnel costs for key faculty, staff, and outreach recruiters responsible for implementing and reporting on the CHW 2025 program, in addition to costs for printed curriculum materials and public recruitment campaigns. Each expense is aligned with HRSA-approved activities and is essential for the continued success and compliance of the program.
Please let us know if any additional documentation or clarification is needed.

recipient_justification: The Primary Care HIV Prevention (PCHP) award is a crucial initiative dedicated to strengthening HIV prevention efforts, particularly in underserved communities across Chicago, IL. recipient_justification:
This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount number 23D18HP32116 (the “Award”) for work performed between 9/1/2013 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $35,614.78. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award.  

Item	Cost
Salaries and Wages	$26,305.05
Fringe Benefits	$6,234.29
Supplies	$437.31
Indirect Costs	$2,638.13
Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$35,614.78

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science. According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS). 

The objective of the Award is to enhance the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science (CDU) Health Careers Opportunity Program, which is designed to prepare students graduating from health professions programs for successful careers in health professions through a structured, clinically focused educational pathway. The program is composed of three key components:
•	Ambassador Program: This component provides 125 undergraduate, post-baccalaureate, and graduate students with a comprehensive pathway that integrates academic, social, and financial s resources. The program aims to support students in developing the necessary skills and knowledge to excel in health professions.
•	Summer Program: This component offers an intensive educational experience for 125 students, focusing on clinical skills development and practical application of healthcare knowledge with 6 hours of daily enrichment activities for 6 weeks. The stipend program is designed to enhance students' readiness for advanced health professional education and training through the development of a range of clinical, public health and academic skills, as well as the cultivation of meaningful professional experiences.
•	Pre-Matriculation Program: Conducted during the summer, this program targets 125 high school students with an interest in pursuing careers in healthcare. This stipend program aims to improve program participants’ understanding of community health through preparation for future studies in health-related fields through a curriculum that emphasizes clinical skills, healthcare education, math enrichment workshops, and SAT preparation courses. 
Overall, over the five-year award period, the project will engage 375 students primarily living in Los Angeles County in a formal, longitudinal pipeline that supports students to enter and successfully complete health professional graduate education and enter the healthcare profession and industry.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Cancer Prevention Services Program Overview
Ellenville Regional Hospital was awarded a grant from the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) to establish a Cancer Prevention Services Program. This initiative addresses the critical need to reduce the disproportionately high rates of late-stage cancer diagnoses in the rural communities of Wawarsing and its surrounding areas.
The program’s primary objective is to improve compliance with national cancer screening guidelines, thereby lessening the impact and severity of advanced cancer cases. The region faces several significant challenges, including persistent poverty, inadequate access to healthcare, and systemic barriers that hinder the receipt of timely and effective medical services. These factors contribute to heightened cancer disparities and overall poorer health outcomes.
The service area consists of geographically isolated and resource-limited communities that struggle with socioeconomic hardships. These challenges create considerable obstacles to accessing and utilizing preventive screenings such as mammograms, colonoscopies, and low dose computed tomography (LDCT) scans.
To combat these issues, a comprehensive work plan was developed and implemented with the following goals:
•	Integrate the Cancer Prevention Services Program into the existing Rural Health Wellness Workgroup.
•	Increase the number of mammograms, colonoscopies, and LDCT scans completed according to recommended screening guidelines.
•	Promote cancer prevention through community education, outreach efforts, and individual coaching.
•	Provide nutrition education and personalized coaching to support healthier lifestyles.
•	Expand tobacco cessation programming as a key cancer prevention strategy.
These goals are being accomplished through evidence-based interventions that engage both healthcare providers and community members.
Expenditures: February and March 2025
During this reporting period, program expenditures were allocated as follows:
Salary and Fringe Benefits
•	Project Director: Oversight of program implementation, supervision of personnel, and monitoring of performance metrics.
•	Project Coordinator: Ensured timely achievement of work plan milestones and supported the Community Health Worker, including facilitating workshops on cancer prevention and nutrition.
•	Community Health Worker: Conducted direct outreach, cancer screening education, and provided one-on-one nutrition coaching.
Contractor Payments
•	Payments were made to The Institute for Family Health for services rendered by the Care Navigator, Supervisor, and Director. The Care Navigator focused on patient outreach and education around cancer screenings within primary care settings, thereby extending the program’s reach.
Travel and Mileage
•	Covered local travel for staff conducting community engagement activities, including client visits, workshops, and flyer distribution.
•	Included travel costs for the Project Director and Coordinator to attend the Annual Grantee Meeting and Conference held at the Georgia Tech Conference Center in Atlanta. This event provided valuable networking opportunities and exposure to best practices in the field.
Other Expenditures
•	Procurement of a work-issued mobile phone for the Community Health Worker.
•	Reimbursement stipend for the coordinator’s use of a personal phone for official duties.
•	Purchase of outreach and marketing materials through VistaPrint.
•	Acquisition of health and wellness journals to support health coaching sessions.

recipient_justification:
The Grant is for Health Center Program Service Expansion-School Based Services Sites (SBSS) project.  This allowed Valley Health Team to participate in the service expansion project for school-based sites.  We partnered with Kings River Union Elementary School District (KRUESD) to open a school-based site on their grounds of Kings River Union Elementary (KRUE) in Kingsburg, California.  
The new SBSS will offer behavioral health services to provide early identification and intervention for students in need of mental health care.  The new SBSS serve as a hub from where VHT behavioral health clinicians will provide on-campus, face-to-face behavioral health screening and therapy, as well as health education, to all eligible district students identified in need of services
Funds were used to pay for the Wages and Fringe Benefits of the Licensed Clinical Psychologist (1FTE), Behavioral Health Case Manager (1FTE), and Director of Behavioral Health Services (.10 FTE) for the months of February 2025 and March 2025.

recipient_justification:
The Behavioral Health Workforce Education and Training Program provides funding to implement a Certified Recovery Support Specialist (CRSS) training and internship program in Central and Southern Illinois. The program will provide didactic and experiential learning through in person training and use of online, telehealth and the ECHO (Extending Community Health Outcomes) Hub to reach students, parents, and educators. Advisory groups will be formed to oversee the program and the Center for Clinical Research will design and collect data to be used for program evaluation.

recipient_justification:
USC Health Resources and Services Administration Scholarship for Disadvantaged Students: Primary Care Project 
This one-year scholarship is available annually to campus-based and Virtual Academic Center (VAC) students enrolled in the MSW program who will graduate in the spring or summer semesters of their last year.

Eligibility Criteria
The scholarship will be awarded to students who are committed to providing behavioral health/primary care services in medically underserved communities (MUCs) in Southern California and throughout the United States. To be eligible, recipients must complete qualified practicum placements that offer direct practice in integrated health/behavioral health settings. 

Two MSW students were identified to qualify for the 2025 (HRSA) Scholarship for Disadvantaged Students (SDS). They each received a total of $31,904 for their tuition assistance. They received their first scholarship payment in January 2025 and second disbursement April 2025. Please see below justification. 

https://dworakpeck.usc.edu/admissions/tuition-and-financial-aid/paying-for-graduate-school/stipends/primary-care-project

recipient_justification:
This payment request is a reimbursement for expenses incurred during the period of February 22, 2025, to April 11, 2025. The expenses include costs related to salaries, fringe benefits, and outside services, and are in direct support of the activities outlined in our approved budget and project scope.

Award Description:
The award supports the Behavioral Health Workforce Education and Training Program to Integrate Mental Health into Primary Care: Training for Social Work. This project aims to strengthen the behavioral health workforce by preparing social work trainees to deliver integrated mental health services within primary care settings.

Use of Funds:
The reimbursed expenses cover:

Salaries and Fringe Benefits: Compensation for project staff and faculty involved in curriculum delivery, trainee supervision, and administrative coordination during the reporting period.

Outside Services: Contracted professional services that support training delivery, program evaluation, or related activities essential to the project’s goals.

All expenditures are consistent with the approved budget and directly contribute to advancing the objectives of the training program.

Please let me know if you need any additional information or supporting documentation.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: The purpose of this grant is to address workforce challenges by supporting public health job development, training, and placement in rural communities. The Maine Workforce Initiative (ME WIN) is funded through the Federal Office of Rural Health Policy’s Rural Public Health Workforce Training Program. MPCA was the sole primary care association awarded this funding. Through the ME WIN program, MPCA convenes a consortium of Maine FQHCs and training partners to strategize and collaborate on a shared goal of building and strengthening recruitment, training, and retention pathways for medical and dental assistants, and Community Health Workers.  These funds are used to pay for staff salaries, contract for subject matter experts and offer financial support for training of health care professionals.

recipient_justification: The expenses for this month included payment of stipends to students, per the purpose of the grant - to provide educational support to students in mental health professions completing a graduate education. Expenses also included payment of staff salaries to manage the project. Management of the project includes facilitation of community outreach projects, analysis of data already collected by the research team, management of interprofessional lab teams, and handling administrative responsibilities. Students received travel reimbursement for travel over 50 miles to community outreach events where students provided public education on mental health and wellness, prevention, and career pathways to mental health professions. Students also provided direct counseling and psychological services as part of their internships in school and community mental health settings.  Faculty and staff provided Interprofessional Education and Practice (IPEP) training to student lab teams. Community outreach included education for individuals, families, school personnel, and first responders.

recipient_justification: HRSA Grant 24DE3RH53719 – SUD Recovery Supports & Unsheltered Housing  In May 2025, ICGH continued its mission to address Substance Use Disorder (SUD) and housing instability through the deployment of integrated recovery supports and transitional housing for unsheltered individuals. The funding supported salaries and fringe for licensed professionals, project staff, and peer support specialists who provided outreach, case management, and daily recovery-based support.  A total of 15 recovery housing beds across our Havelock and Davis locations were maintained, delivering stable, sober environments for individuals transitioning from homelessness or crisis care into long-term recovery pathways. Our peer support specialists, all with lived experience, offered on-site support while the healthcare navigator and project coordinator ensured access to MAT, behavioral health, and wraparound services.  Additionally, our partnership with CSI Data Evaluator Team ensured that measurable outcomes and

recipient_justification: Craven County received Capital Assistance for Hurricane Response & Recovery Efforts (CARE) funding in September 2023 which allowed for capital-related resources to support alteration, renovation, construction, equipment, and other capital improvement costs. Craven County is using this funding for a Construction/Expansion project of an existing facility. Our current facility is approximately 4,000 sq. ft. and the expansion will consist of an additional 2,000 sq. ft. The additional 2,000 sq. ft. will allow for 3 additional exam rooms, 1 work-up room, a pharmacy room, and additional office space. We expect completion of this project by June 30th. The use of the funds will cover the architectural & engineering fees and the cost of the construction/expansion of the project.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the continued implementation of our Maternal and Child Health Federal Consolidated Programs, which are essential to promoting the health, safety, and well-being of women, infants, children, including those with special health care needs, and families across our jurisdiction. The funding will be used to carry out program activities authorized under Title V of the Social Security Act, and aligns with the priorities of Executive Order 14222 by advancing access to care, reducing health disparities, and ensuring accountability in outcomes. This payment will fund personnel, outreach activities, data collection and evaluation, and direct services through contracted partners.

recipient_justification:
The purpose of the HRSA H80 School-Based Services (SBSS) grant is to increase access to healthcare and behavioral health services through delivery sites located in schools, in compliance with Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act. Specifically, the funding is used to expand services at existing school-based sites, establish new ones, or open the first school-based service site for a Health Center Program grant recipient. 

This specific request is for funding that Family Health Centers, a non-profit healthcare organization, will use to operate and support 6 service sites in schools in Okanogan County, WA, a rural, low income region with limited access to consistent, comprehensive medical and dental care. These funds will be used to pay for the wages of clinical and non-clinical personnel, supplies, and utilities that are required to run the program. Family Health Centers supplies the schools with nurses, behavioral health providers, and community health workers who administer care to students on site, and arrange telehealth visits for students with offsite providers.

recipient_justification: This drawdown supports salaries and fringe benefits tied to increasing access to mental health and substance use disorder (SUD) services, including medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD). Mental health and SUDs are critical issues in LA County, with high rates of unmet need. Children’s Hospital LA’s 2022 assessment found 27.5% of teens needed help with mental health, rising to 70% in juvenile justice populations. SUD affects over 17% of LA County residents 12+, yet only 1% of health center patients receive services. Staffing supports include MDs, LCSWs, nurses, care coordinators, and pharmacists delivering direct care, case management, and wraparound support.

recipient_justification:
Suncoast Community Health Centers is using the grant fundings to cover the cost of venous blood HIV tests and associated reference lab costs. 
SCHC is using the funds granted to cover the cost of any reflex testing needs in the event the initial test comes back positive.
SCHC Outreach workers add the venous HIV tests to the panel of screening they perform to increase testing in the community.
Currently, we use the number of tests performed monthly times an approximate rate cost for this expense. 
These funds allow SCHC carry out the goals of the Primary Care HIV Prevention Grant.

recipient_justification:
North Country Healthcare (NCHC), accredited as a sponsoring institution since 2014, currently holds a status of “Continued Accreditation Effective 1/13/2025” with no citations. As part of its strategic initiative to expand graduate medical education, NCHC has formally initiated an application for a Psychiatry Residency Program in the ACGME Accreditation Data System (ADS).

In support of the accreditation process, NCHC has partnered with Wipfli, LLC, a consulting firm providing expertise in GME program development. This collaboration has yielded a full draft of the required accreditation materials, including:

Rotation block diagram

Didactic curriculum

Policies and procedures

Program application

Rotation goals and objectives

Resident and faculty evaluation surveys

During this quarter, NCHC successfully secured Core Faculty commitments from clinical partners at The Guidance Center and Flagstaff Medical Center, strengthening the program’s educational foundation.

The final remaining documentation includes Program Letters of Agreement (PLAs), which are currently being circulated among affiliated sites for signatures.

The grant supporting this initiative continues to fund key components of the program’s development, including personnel costs for the Program Director, consulting fees, and related operating expenses such as travel.

Salary and benefits for Program Director, Dr. Danielle Lindner, because she leads and implements the BHWET Hatters Behavioral Health Coalition program and oversees the overall operations of the program. She oversees the Practicum and Internship Coordinator, program faculty, and Advisory Council, liaise with and assists in the oversight of all external and internal partners to the grant, develops curriculum, manages the program budget, conducts internal evaluation procedures, and ensures transfer of all required data to the external evaluator. This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount Number 22H76HA02163 (the “Award”) for work performed between 5/1/2022 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $20,585.87. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award.  

Item	Cost
Salaries and Wages	$16,477.00
Fringe Benefits	$3,905.05
Indirect Costs	$203.82
Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$20,585.87

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science.  According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS).

The objective of this Award is to support the provision of comprehensive primary health care and support services for individuals living with HIV in an outpatient setting. This initiative is facilitated through the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science’s (CDU) OASIS Clinic, which is dedicated to delivering early intervention and ongoing primary care services to persons living with HIV in Los Angeles County. The program aims to achieve the following clinical objectives:
•	Comprehensive Care Delivery: Provide a full spectrum of primary health care services tailored to meet the needs of individuals living with HIV, ensuring continuity of care and improved health outcomes.
•	Early Intervention Services: Implement early intervention strategies to identify and address HIV-related health issues promptly, reducing the progression of the disease and enhancing patient quality of life.
•	Ongoing Support and Management: Offer ongoing medical support and management for individuals living with HIV, focusing on maintaining optimal health and preventing complications.
The payment request associated with the Award is intended to reimburse expenses related to the delivery of these essential health services, including personnel costs, medical supplies, and expenses necessary for the effective functioning of the OASIS Clinic.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award
org_name: CHARLES R DREW UNIVERSITY OF MEDICINE & SCIENCE

This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount number - 23TA2HP48938 (the “Award”) for work performed between 12/31/2022 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $20,316.84. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award.  

Item	Cost

Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$20,316.84

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science. According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS). 
The objective of the Award is to establish a comprehensive training program within the university’s Family Medicine Residency to enhance the clinical competencies of family medicine physicians in identifying and managing mental and behavioral health conditions among children, adolescents, and young adults (up to 29 years old). The program is structured to provide progressive learning and mastery over three years:
•	Year 1 - Foundational Principles: Residents will acquire essential knowledge and understanding of mental and behavioral health conditions, focusing on early identification and assessment techniques.
•	Year 2 - Application of Knowledge: Residents will apply their foundational knowledge in clinical settings, developing practical skills in diagnosing and managing mental and behavioral health issues.
•	Year 3 - Mastery and Specialization: Residents will achieve mastery in mental and behavioral health care, with opportunities to specialize in areas such as pediatric and adolescent psychiatry.
To ensure comprehensive clinical exposure, the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science (CDU), College of Medicine (COM) will collaborate with CDU-affiliated clinics and community-based organizations. These partnerships will provide residents with diverse clinical experiences is to enhance the knowledge and skills of primary care physicians.

recipient_justification: Drawdown request covers personnel, fringe and indirect costs  to execute approved workplans to inform family planning services with input from patients (42 U.S.C. § 300(a)).  The approved budget line categories are Personnel and Fringe. Specifically, during the period 4/16-4/30, project activities included: 1) Scheduling 5 interviews with patients about their sexual and reproductive health experiences, conducting an interview with 1 patient, and transcribing and summarizing interviews; 2) meetings with our team to discuss data collection and analysis of interview and survey data; 3) analyses to understand patient satisfaction and preferences in family planning, as well as whether providers were responsive to patient preferences; and 4) outlining and writing two publications on patient satisfaction and preferences.

recipient_justification:
"April payroll for HMF emplyees.
May Rent for HMF
Payment to Florence Crittenton and Mineral County Health Department for their financial support of one staff in each agency to be trained as trainers in the Erikson Institute's Facilitating Attuned Interaction Reflective Supervision Training.
Indirect Costs (DPHHS employees in the Early Childhood and Family Support Division work on multiple federal grants; therefore, their payroll, rent, and other corresponding administration is cost allocated based on statistics of how much time was spent working on each grant (please also see Montana’s PACAP).   As Montana only processes actual cost allocation results on a quarterly basis, daily estimated indirects are posted to each federal grant, based on a daily average from the previous quarter’s actual cost allocation results.   This draw covers that daily estimated amount and will be reconciled to actuals at the end of the quarter.)"

recipient_justification:
Organization: KENNEBEC VALLEY FAMILY DENTISTRY (KVFD)
Program: CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED SPENDING CAPITAL PROJECTS 
Grant Number: CE1HS52129
Additional Clarification: This payment request of $18,140.40 is for the purchase of a complete dental chair setup under our Congressionally Directed Spending (CDS) capital project for the Kennebec Valley Family Dentistry Clinic Expansion. The equipment package (per quote #9577 dated 3/20/2025) requested includes:

- ULTRATRIM CONCEPT LR CHAIR ($8,101.24)
- PROCENTER CONCEPT LR INST instrumentation delivery system ($5,918.60)
- LED LR OPERATING LIGHT PROCNTR ceiling-mounted light ($3,334.71)
- Handpiece Illumination System ($416.83)
- ISO-C FO Straight Tubing in Soothing Blue color ($189.41)
- Shipping and handling ($179.61)

This dental operatory package is an essential component for one of our new treatment rooms and directly supports our CDS-approved goal of expanding clinical capacity to serve more patients. This specific chair setup will enable us to provide comprehensive dental care to Kennebec County, including patients who struggle to find dental providers.

The equipment purchase aligns with our approved project plan and budget for expanding clinical capabilities as outlined in our original CDS application. This operatory is one of several being installed as part of our clinic expansion project, which also includes the development of an Ambulatory Surgical Center for dental services to provide more advanced care within our community.

Please specify if further clarification is needed. Thank you.

recipient_justification: Staffing comprised of 57 hours for Pediatric Provider and 160 hours of patient coordination and grant coordination. The following expenditures are supported by the personnel and other costs in accordance with the approved grant budget: Expenditures supported providing developmental screenings to a minimum of 1,000 patients, conducting 24 outreach events, ensuring that all patients that screen positive or approximately 200 patients annually receive appropriate follow-up services within 30 days of a developmental screening. La Maestra has exceed all program goals. From 9/1/24 to 3/31/25, the organization conducted 2,240  developmental screenings. Exceeding the program goal by 124%. La Maestra was also able to conduct 21 outreach events to promote additional developmental delay screenings now offered at La Maestra. Of the 2,240 patients screened, 145 patients screened positive and received appropriate follow up services with a community partner within 30 days.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: Justification for Grant Funds – April 2025 (Part B)  The requested grant funds totaling $17,257.90 support essential services for individuals in treatment for substance use disorders (SUDs), with a focus on recovery supports, staffing, and outreach to unsheltered individuals. Personnel costs ($8,913.14) include licensed clinical oversight, peer support specialists, project coordination, and navigation staff—all vital for engaging and retaining individuals in recovery. Fringe benefits ($2,852.20) ensure workforce stability and coverage, while contractual costs ($2,312.46) directly support access to Medication-Assisted Treatment (MAT) and essential medications. Travel expenses ($3,180.10) enable peer support and outreach staff to connect with unsheltered individuals across rural areas, ensuring equitable access to care and housing. This funding ensures an integrated and person-centered approach to addressing the opioid crisis and supporting long-term recovery.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: To maintain continuity in HIV prevention efforts under the PCHP grant, we request drawdown of funds aligned with our approved budget. Supplies are needed for HIV testing kits, PrEP materials, and PPE. Travel supports staff training and outreach in high-need areas. Contractual services with labs, telehealth, and peer navigators expand PrEP access and linkage to care. Other costs cover health education, data systems, and client support services like transport. Timely access to funds ensures uninterrupted delivery of services and supports core goals: increased HIV testing, PrEP uptake, and care linkage.

recipient_justification: This drawdown request of $16,393.54 supports staffing, addiction treatment services, and travel related to addiction recovery and recovery housing services under HRSA Grant 24DE3RH53719 for May 2025. Personnel costs (\$8,913.14) cover key staff including the Project Director, Clinical Director, Peer Support Specialists, and others providing direct recovery support and coordination from May 12–23. Fringe benefits (\$2,852.20) reflect standard 32% rates for insurance and worker’s compensation. Contractual costs (\$3,000.00) fund four treatment bundles delivered in April, supporting clients in structured outpatient recovery programs. Travel reimbursements (\$1,628.20) support mileage for outreach and client transport by peer staff during April. All costs are allowable, reasonable, and essential to achieving program goals focused on reducing substance use and supporting housing stability.

recipient_justification: The following expenditures are supported by the personnel and other costs in accordance with the approved grant budget:  Staffing comprised of 45 hours for Pediatric Provider and 160 hours of patient coordination and grant coordination. Expenditures supported providing developmental screenings to a minimum of 1,000 patients, conducting 24 outreach events, ensuring that all patients that screen positive or approximately 200 patients annually receive appropriate follow-up services with 30 days of a developmental screening. La Maestra has exceed all program goals. During the project period from 9/1/24 to 2/28/25, the organization conducted 2,201  developmental screenings. Exceeding the program goals by 102.1%. La Maestra has also conducted 18 outreach events to promote additional developmental delay screenings now offered at La Maestra. Of the 2,201 patients screened, 144 patients screened positive and received appropriate follow-up services with a community partner within 30 days.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
This award provides Behavioral Health Service Expansion (BHSE) funding.  The purpose of BHSE funding is to support health centers to increase access to behavioral health services through starting or expanding mental health and substance use disorder services.  The two objectives of the funding are to increase the number of patients receiving mental health services and increase the number of patients receiving SUD services.  

Our plan for the funds in Year 1 included hiring 5 additional full time employees (2 Behavioral Health Counselors, 1 Behavioral Health Therapist, 1 Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner, and 1 RN/LPN), and purchasing  a RapidPak RX machine to support medication adherence for mental health prescriptions. 

This payment request covers the wages and fringe benefits of the employees that have been hired under the BHSE Grant for the pay date of 4/24/2025.

recipient_justification:
This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount number 22T52HP46759C6 (the “Award”) for work performed 9/30/2022 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $14,932.20. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award. 
 
Item	Cost
Salaries and Wages	$11,177.13
Fringe Benefits	$2,648.98
Indirect Costs	$1,106.09
Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$14,932.20

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science.  According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS). 

The objective of this award is to fortify the public health workforce by supporting Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science (CDU) in establishing a scholarship program. This program is designed to incentivize individuals to pursue advanced training and careers in public health. Key components include:
•	Public Health System Enhancement: The program is structured to strengthen the public health system by ensuring that trained professionals are equipped to meet critical health service needs.
•	Scholarship Provision: CDU offers scholarships to individuals for public health training in professional, graduate degree, and certificate programs. This initiative aims to cultivate a skilled workforce capable of addressing core public health functions and delivering the Ten Essential Public Health Services as shown below:
o	Assess and monitor population health.
o	Investigate, diagnose and address health hazards and root causes.
o	Communicate effectively to inform and educate.
o	Strengthen, support and mobilize communities and partnerships.
o	Create, champion and implement policies, plans and laws.
o	Utilize legal and regulatory actions.
o	Enable equitable access.
o	Build a diverse and skilled workforce.
o	Improve and innovate through evaluation, research and quality improvement. 
o	Build and maintain a strong organizational infrastructure for public health.

•	Recruitment and Matriculation Support: The award facilitates increased recruitment activities for public health students, encouraging enrollment in CDU’s Public Health Programs.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.
org_name: CHARLES R DREW UNIVERSITY OF MEDICINE & SCIENCE

recipient_justification: This grant provides support for expanding the Maine Primary Care Association Patient Safety Organization ( MePCA PSO.) Through the MePCA PSO, providers work to improve the quality of the health care provided in their healthcare settings and focus on patient and environmental safety. It provides a protective collaborative framework for its members to work cooperatively to evaluate, address and share learnings regarding patient care to achieve quality and safety goals. Ultimately, the work of MePCA PSO and its providers is focused on improving clinical outcomes, saving lives, and providing the best quality, patient safety, service, and value. This grant builds on the RHND planning grant.  Funds were used to pay for staff and consultant salaries, some conference expenses and other contracted support and administrative items as approved.

Raj Appavu

recipient_justification:
The Nursing Workforce Diversity (NWD) project focuses on educating, training, and mentoring students from disadvantaged populations, particularly cultural/racial minorities and low socioeconomic status facing social and economic barriers to education and professional success. 

The May 6, 2025 payment request of $13,792.77 is for the reimbursement of the following grant costs incurred since the last request: 
●	Personnel: $9,395.20
●	Fringe Benefits: $3,161.07
●	Indirect Costs: $1,236.50

Project Manager: $6,771.20 salary. Included in the budget
The Project Manager supports the overall project and synchronizes efforts across University departments and non-university partners to coordinate the overall development, delivery, data collection, and reporting of the HRSA Nursing Workforce Diversity project. The Project Manager also oversees the program’s day-to-day operations in conjunction with the School of Nursing Director and the Project Evaluators. 

Student Success: $1,624 additional pay for student success duties. Included in the budget
Student success is part of the NWD project Academic Advising, responsible for tracking progress and collecting data related to the recruitment, enrollment, and retention/completion of first-year BSN students supported through the UMaine NWD project. Data will include individual and aggregate data that are measures of student performance and student feedback about the academic and social supports offered through the Living Learning Community.

$1,000 PATFA salary for teaching NUR 415. Included in the budget under 50016 - Fall overloads
Part-time adjunct faculty member who teaches NUR 415 Socio-Cultural Issues in Health and Health Care. Her role aligns with Goal 3 of the NWD approved proposal: Increase exposure and representation of racial minorities among the University of Maine School of Nursing faculty by 25%.


Fringe Benefits: $3,161.07 includes full benefits at 43.7%, amounting to $2,959.02 for the professional salaried position. It also includes temporary benefits (7.7%) for the additional pay and the overload, amounting to $202.05. 

Indirect costs: $1,236.50 of indirect costs were calculated in accordance with our federally negotiated indirect cost rate agreement and the terms of the award agreement.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
"We are requesting payment under the Health Center Program (Federal Award Project Title: Health Center Program; Assistance Listing Number: 93.224; Assistance Listing Program Title: Community Health Centers), authorized by 42 USC § 254b, and funded under Federal Award Identification Number (FAIN): H8024103. This drawdown will support clinic operations by covering personnel costs for clinical and administrative staff.  
The funds will be applied to salaries, wages, and benefits for physicians, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, and other licensed healthcare professionals who deliver direct patient care in our health center locations. In addition, the drawdown will support essential operations through funding for front office staff, medical assistants, care team coordinators, and other administrative roles needed to providing timely and efficient care.
Our health center delivers primary care medical and BH services to individuals regardless of ability to pay, as required by statute"

recipient_justification:
This draw down is aligned with Grant H8NCS54189‐01‐00.  Spending on salaries and fringe benefits is fully aligned with the grant agreement and is in scope to achieve project objectives of increasing the number of patients who receive mental health services, as well as increasing the number of patients who receive substance use disorder (SUD) services, including medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD).”
Mental health disorders are a significant public health problem, both in their own right and because they are often associated with many other chronic diseases. Untreated disorders may leave individuals at risk for substance abuse and other self-destructive behavior. Additionally, mental health disorders can have a serious impact on physical health and are associated with the prevalence, progression, and outcome of chronic diseases. The effects of mental illness range from minor disruptions in daily functioning to incapacitating personal, social, and occupational impairments and early death.
Notably, Children’s Hospital of Los Angeles’ 2022 Community Health Needs Assessment highlighted mental health as a growing critical health challenge in LA County and throughout California. Over a quarter of teens (27.5%) in LA County reported needing help with mental or emotional issues with the highest need in Service Provision Area (SPA) 4 with this need rising to 70% of youth in the juvenile justice system. According to SAMSHA, 73.1% of children receiving mental health treatment had a serious emotional disturbance and 74.2% of adults had a serious mental illness.
Relatedly, substance use disorders are highly correlated with high rates of mental health conditions. In 2022, the LA County Department of Public Health found that the estimated population of residents 12 years of age or older1 in need of SUD treatment was over 17%. This translates to over 1.4 million people in LA County alone. More broadly, only 1% of health center patients are using SUD services vs the estimate of 17% who could use this help, with the real rate of need being almost certainly higher.
Even amongst children the rates are high: nearly 7% of children 12 and older in SPA 4 of Los Angeles County were already misusing pain relievers. In LA County, there are approximately 3,000 alcohol and drug related deaths every year, and nearly 148,000 annual alcohol or other drug (AOD)-related emergency room visits. In SPA 4 of LA County, 8.2 percent of service area residents (age 12+) reported dependence or abuse of illicit drugs or alcohol in the past year, a rate that is likely far higher if under-reporting is taken into account.
Alarmingly, data from the California Department of Public Health show that fentanyl-related deaths have increased exponentially over the last 10 years — and have more than tripled since only 2019. The increase is so significant, that in 2012, data show that 82 fentanyl-related deaths were reported to the department. By 2019, the number grew to 1,603 — before exploding to 5,722 in 2021.
Clearly, there are high rates of mental health disorders and SUDs in Los Angeles County and more resources are required to address these conditions.
STAFF Spending – 
MD Doctor – Providing SUD treatment and training to other physicians on addiction counseling. 
Director of Behavioral Health  – overseeing the program staff in behavioral health/ program design and oversight
Psychiatric Nurse – providing care to SUD patients – injectables. 
Care Coordinators/ Case Managers – SCC’s care management/ coordination team provides LYFT services for patients without reliable transportation to and from appointments, connects patients to housing resources through our transitional housing partners, provides linkages to employment service organizations, as well as provides additional food resources through partnerships with The Hollywood Food Coalition or Project Food Box.
LCSWs – providing mental health treatment to mental health diagnosis, as well as dual diagnosis patients. 
Clinical Pharmacist – providing medications for patients with SUD/ BH diagnosis.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.
