recipient_justification:
The University of Maine HRSA – Graduate Psychology Education (GPE) program seeks to expand access to evidence-based prevention and treatment services for behavioral health, including opioid use and substance use disorders, in underserved areas of rural Maine. One of the program’s objectives is to develop clinical psychology students’ competencies in integrated behavioral health through experiential and didactic training. To achieve this objective, students provide behavioral health service in primary care offices under the supervision of licensed psychologists. A second objective is to enhance the relevant competencies of clinical supervisors.  Supervisors participate in professional development in accordance with their individualized plans. A third objective of the program is to expand and improve tele-behavioral health training and services. To support this objective, the university has developed a state-of-the-art tele-behavioral health laboratory.

The payment request of $10,871.45 dated 5/6/25 is for reimbursement of the following grant costs:
	Personnel: $5,462.60
	Fringe Benefits: $2,387.15
	Maintenance: $38.50
	Participant Support Costs $2,228.00
 	Indirects: $755.20
These expenses are in accordance with the grant agreement. The personnel expenses of $5,462.60 covered a portion of the Project Director’s salary; duties include coordinating the students’ clinical placements, providing clinical supervision, organizing professional development activities for clinical supervisors, and managing administrative tasks (e.g., budget, quarterly reports). Fringe costs of $2,387.15 were calculated in accordance with our federally negotiated fringe benefit rates. The maintenance expense of $38.50 was the cost of finishing work on tele-behavioral health laboratory. Participant Support Costs of $2,228.00 provided stipends to doctoral students in clinical psychology who are training in primary care offices in rural Maine as well as reimbursement for mileage to travel to training sites. Indirect costs of $755.20 were calculated in accordance with our federally negotiated indirect cost rate and the terms of the award agreement.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount Number - 20SDS-NP (the “Award”) for work performed between 7/1/2020 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $9,262.44. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award.  

Item	Cost
Scholarship costs	$8,264.92
Supplies	$950.02
Travel	$47.50
Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$9,262.44

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science.  According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS).

The objective of this Award is to enhance the recruitment and retention strategies for Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science’s (CDU) Master of Public Health (MPH) Program. The program aims to achieve the following clinical objectives:
•	Recruitment Enhancement: Implement targeted recruitment activities to increase the number of students enrolling in the MPH Program, thereby addressing the local public health workforce needs.
•	Retention and Graduation Support: Strengthen retention initiatives to ensure MPH students complete their degrees within 150% of the standard completion time, contributing to a higher graduation rate and a robust public health workforce.
The payment request associated with this Award is intended to reimburse expenses related to scholarships, grants, and supplies necessary for the successful execution of the program. These costs are essential to achieving the program's objectives and supporting the development of skilled public health professionals.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.
org_name: CHARLES R DREW UNIVERSITY OF MEDICINE & SCIENCE

recipient_justification:
The funds requested is for reimbursement of the wages and Fringe Benefits of the Director of Behavioral Health employee (0.25 FTE) for the months of February and March, working on the implementation of the BHI-EB-TNP project under the SubAccount 24UL8TH53333.
The purpose of the project is to identify through a combination of focus groups, community surveys, and key informant interviews the most important and pressing health need in Fresno County.  VHT’s health system will improve access to integrated behavioral health services for the target population by spreading the PCBH evidence-based model of care to two rural health center sites.  Originating Sites: VHT’s network will consist of two Originating sites and one Distant site. Originating sites are both rural and located in designated MUAs. During calendar year 2023, the Originating sites served 5,864 patients. Over the 5-year project period these sites will provide PCBH care to 240 patients a year via telehealth.

recipient_justification: These funds support personnel costs for staff working to administer Pennsylvania’s approved Child and Family Services Plan. This $8942.10 payment covers staff salary ($5143.50) and associated benefits ($3798.60) for two positions for the period from March 14 to March 28, 2025.  These individuals are responsible for monitoring grantees, providing technical assistance, reporting, and continued development of the Maternal, Infant & Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) Program.  These payments support the delivery of evidence-based home visiting services to vulnerable and at-risk pregnant and parenting families in Pennsylvania; manage the Commonwealth's 24- hour toll-free helpline to provide resources that protect newborns who might otherwise be abandoned or harmed; deliver foundational (core) skills training to provide child welfare professionals with the fundamental awareness, understanding, knowledge, and skills needed to ensure adequate and accurate services to children and their families; and adoption promotion services.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
Program Title: Community Project Funding/Congressionally Directed Spending – Construction
This grant to the Louisiana Addiction Research Center (LARC) is for the purchase of equipment to expand impactful research on and treatment of chronic substance use disorders by LSU Health Shreveport.

The February 2025 acquisition of advanced desktop computers by the LARC at LSU Health Shreveport aligns with the Health Resources and Services Administration's (HRSA) strategic priorities in addressing chronic health conditions and further supports reproducibility and transparency of research findings, addressing concerns about the replicability of scientific studies. These systems include enhanced video processing and computational capabilities to analyze live-stream data of novel treatments for chronic substance use disorders, specifically methamphetamine and opioid treatments. These systems facilitate rigorous data analysis and validation, enabling LARC to contribute to data-driven decisions and translational research that reflect HRSA's emphasis on readiness, innovation, and high-impact outcomes.

recipient_justification:
Grant award No. 1 U4AMC44239‐02 Request payment for pay date 5/05/2025.    Total $8,440 for personnel $5,059 and fringe benefits $3,381 These positions were approved in the grant budget. 
Requesting payment for the Pediatric Mental Health Care Access (PMHCA) Coordinator position fulfilled by Renzymeir Baloran, and Pediatric Mental Health Care Access (PMHCA) Specialist position fulfilled by Eden Sun funded through the PMHCA grant award. The PMHCA grant supports efforts to improve access to mental health care for children and adolescents (ages 0 to 21) by enhancing the capacity of pediatric primary care providers through training, consultation, and care coordination. Renzy plays a central role in overseeing program activities that advance this mission, including planning and facilitating provider trainings, launching and managing a statewide mental health consultation access line, conducting outreach, and supporting both administrative and financial operations of the grant. Her work directly strengthens provider capacity and expands mental health access for children and families in Hawai‘i. Eden Sun plays a vital role in this effort, providing direct support to the PMHCA. Coordinator and leading all required reporting and data collection activities for the grant She is responsible for preparing detailed reports and presentations that demonstrate program reach and effectiveness, including those presented to pediatric providers, state partners, and other stakeholders.
We certify the payment is allowable, allocable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the NOA.

recipient_justification: Grant funding was used in accordance with the approved expenditures required to substantially renovate an existing building in order to turn it into a drug treatment center opening in November. Funding was used to purchase and install doors, windows, flooring and HVAC mechanical systems. Funding was also used for painting interior walls. This month, use of the funds broke down in the following manner: Purchase and installation of doors and related accessories: $153,189.24. Purchase and installation of windows and storefront glazing: $149.551.23. Interior painting: $451,063. Purchase and installation of flooring including carpeting and vinyl tile: $18,553. Purchase and installation of new HVAC mechanical systems: $175,040. Total expenditures this month: $547,376.47. The total expenditure for the month exceeds the balance of grant funding available. We will use alternative sources of funding to fill this gap.

recipient_justification:
The purpose of the WellNurse project is to increase resiliency and reduce burnout among UMaine Nursing faculty, staff, and students, and to serve as a model to scale across health profession programs at UMaine, the 7-campus UMaine System, and beyond. 

The May 6, 2025 payment request of $7,242.62 is for the reimbursement of the following grant costs incurred since the last request: 
●	Personnel: $5,454.32
●	Fringe Benefits: $1,097.44
●	Supplies & Materials: $103.53
●	Indirect: $587.33

Project Director $2,357.10 salary and related fringe benefits of $1,030.06 at 43.7% 
Project Director directs the School of Nursing’s (SON) efforts toward recruiting students, faculty and staff in Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction training, WellNurse Fitness Program, LiveWell and Peer Mentoring; organizes and oversees the SON Wellness Committee; provides guidance toward the establishment and management of the SON Wellness Room; and oversees data collection and evaluation of the UMaine WellNurse project, and outcomes reporting to HRSA. 

Doctoral Student $2,222.22 salary (included in budget)
The doctoral student from clinical psychology supports project operations, evaluation, and dissemination. Doctoral students will support enrollment and participation tracking in the research evaluation portion of the project (consent process, survey reminders, activity reminders). The student has completed the Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction 8-week training class. Additional duties include cleaning and data management for the project statistician.

$875 pay for NUR 214 and related fringe benefits of $67.38 at 7.7% 
Nursing faculty are teaching NUR 214 Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction for eleven weeks over the semester. NUR 214 is a new course that was created through the project and has 16 students enrolled this semester. This is a 2-credit course and was also approved by the University to meet the criteria for the Artistic and Creative Expression general elective.

Supplies: The $103.53 in supplies includes the purchase of various books on mindfulness (The Trauma-Sensitive Mindfulness Workbook, The Mindful Athlete, The Mamba Mentality, etc.)

Indirect: Indirect costs of $587.33 were calculated in accordance with our federally negotiated indirect cost rate agreement and the terms of the award agreement.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: This drawdown from the QIF-TJI supports staffing and operations linked to improving health care engagement and outcomes for individuals reentering the community from Plymouth County Correction Facility. It supports in reach efforts by BNHC staff at the correctional facility to improve linkage to primary and behavioral health services prior to release. This includes obtaining past medical history, medication lists, ordering known referrals, and screening for social determinants of health. Funds support the operations of BNHC's "Reentry Clinic" staffed by the same medical staff performing inreach, to enhance chronic disease management (i.e. Diabetes, hypertension), infectious disease treatment, substance use disorder treatment, and behavioral health care. All work and requested funds are consistent with our approved budget.

recipient_justification:
Award Number D06RH49156 - Rural Health Outreach and Rural Network Development Program
The Energy Capital Health Network (ECHN) was created to further the collaborative efforts of healthcare entities in the region. Members of the ECHN include CCCHC, Sakakawea Medical Center (SMC; Critical Access Hospital), Knife River Care Center (KRCC; Skilled Nursing Facility), and Custer Health (CH; Public Health). The partner organizations have worked together for years to achieve efficiencies in health care service delivery, expand access to care, improve quality of care and health outcomes, and strengthen the rural health delivery system in west central North Dakota. The funds will be used to support expenses approved on the HRSA budget related to serving rural underserved populations.

The purpose of award 21M01HP41998 is to address the behavioral health care workforce needs in rural Maine by preparing social work and clinical psychology graduate students for careers in rural integrated behavioral health settings.
 
The payment request of $5,958.98, dated 5/6/25, is for reimbursement of the following grant costs: 
Personnel: $3,760.46
Fringe Benefits: $1,643.32
Other Direct Costs: $29.75
Indirect: $525.45

The personnel costs and related fringe benefits are associated with ongoing evaluation activities (conducting key informant interviews, deploying student surveys, preparing data for reporting, and meeting with staff to coordinate efforts), student training (grading final assignments, calculating course grades), and preparation for project closeout (gathering data for final reports, drafting final reports). Other direct costs represent LAN fees associated with ongoing evaluation activities. Indirect costs were calculated in accordance with our federally negotiated indirect cost rate agreement and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification:
The purpose of the Advanced Nursing Education Workforce (ANEW) Program is to increase the number of primary care nurse practitioners, clinical nurse specialists, and certified nurse midwives trained and prepared to provide primary care services, mental health and substance use disorder care, and/or maternal health care. This grant supports the training and graduation of advanced practice registered nursing (APRN) students/trainees in these disciplines. At UMaine, the ANEW grant provides tuition and other eligible supports to FNP students, builds academic-clinical partnerships to facilitate clinical training, and continues to develop and sustain clinical faculty and preceptors.

This draw request of $5,608.66 made on May 6, 2025 is for the reimbursement of the following grant costs incurred since our previous request:
Personnel: $3,637.62
Fringe Benefits: $1,444.47
Indirect: $526.57

The personnel line item includes the salary support for the Simulation Technologist ($1,078.12) and the Project Coordinator ($2,156.25) for this grant. The Project Coordinator oversees the ANEW program day-to-day operations, in conjunction with the Project Director. The simulation technologist works to integrate the new simulations into NP clinical curriculum and is responsible for the use and maintenance of the audio/visual equipment as well as standardized patient program. The other salary line item is the additional pay ($403.25) for the Finance Manager overseeing the grant. This position coordinates disbursement of trainee and preceptor funds in the different semesters. Additionally, the Finance Manager maintains the budget and associated reconciliation protocols. Fringe benefits ($1,444.47) include full benefits at 43.7%, amounting to $1,413.42 for the two professional salaried positions. It also includes temporary benefits (7.7%) for the additional pay, amounting to $31.05. All of these positions were included in the budget justification and have been a part of the grant since it started. Indirect costs of $526.57 were calculated in accordance with our federally negotiated indirect cost rate and the terms of the award agreement.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

This is a payment request for $4,725.02 on the Health Resources and Services Administration grant number 5 D18HP32121‐07‐00. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $3,339.71, Fringe Benefits $1,035.31, and Indirect Costs $350.00 subtotal $4,725.02 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Health Careers Opportunity Program. The purpose of this grant program is to assist students from disadvantaged backgrounds to enter and successfully complete health profession schools in accordance with section 739 of the Public Health Service Act. It has no component involving illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or assessing gender ideology issues and we certify that the costs are not used for such research activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with NOFO Announcement HRSA-23-003 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance

recipient_justification:
This request is for reimbursement for cost already paid for personnel, fringe, supplies, travel, contractual, and other.  These cost include but are not limited to: 

Budget Justification	Grant Request
Personnel [For full position descriptions, see Attachment 6]
Project Director. Caleb Cox. ARHP requests federal funding for an ARHP staff member to dedicate .50fte to this project to serve as the Project Director to provide oversight, specifically acting as the spokesperson for project initiatives and oversight of all project efforts.(See Job Description in Attachment 4) [$68,000/annual ARHP salary @ .50fte=
$34,000/year]	$34,000
Project Coordinator, Capstone Student. ARHP requests federal funding of $12,000 and ARHP will match $12,000 for a University of Arkansas Clinton School of Public Service second-year graduate student who will work under the ARHP CEO & President to assist with the project throughout the year as the Project Coordinator.(See Job Description in Attachment 4) [$25/hour x 80 hours/month (.50fte) = $24,000/year]	$12,000
Network Director. Mellie Boagni Bridewell. ARHP will fund the ARHP CEO & President to dedicate .05FTE to this project to serve as the Network Director to ensure all partnering organizations are involved. Ms. Bridewell will also be responsible for initiating a statewide workforce task force that will include state, education, and healthcare partners.(See Job Description in Attachment 4) [$208,250/annual ARHP salary @ .05FTE= $10,413/year]	$0
Senior Program Evaluation Specialist (SPEC). Camille Watson. ARHP will fund the ARHP SPES to oversee all program evaluation activities. This position will assist with developing and supervising the data collection process and project evaluation. (See Job Description in Attachment 4) [$52,000/annual salary @ .10fte = $5,200/year]	$0
Total Personnel	$46,000
Fringe Benefits [For full position descriptions, see Attachment 6]
Project Director. Caleb Cox. ARHP requests federal funding for an ARHP staff member to dedicate .50fte to this project to serve as the Project Director. (See Job Description in Attachment 4) ($14,864/annual ARHP fringe benefits @ .50fte=
$7,432/year).	$7,432
Senior Program Evaluation Specialist. Camille Watson. ARHP will fund the Senior Program Evaluation Specialists to provide data analytics, data collection, data reporting, grant reporting, and final analysis for the proposed project.(See Job Description in Attachment 4) (The fringe benefits are $6,438/annual fringe @ 0.10fte= $644).	$0
Network Director. Mellie Boagni Bridewell. ARHP will fund the ARHP CEO & President to dedicate 0.05 FTE to this project to serve as the Network Director. (See Job Description in Attachment 4) ($20,068/annual fringe benefit cost @ 0.05 FTE= $1,003/year)	$0
Total Fringe Benefits	$7,432
Supplies
Office Supplies. ARHP will provide funding of $800 in Year I to purchase copies, paper, ink, and general office supplies for all project staff.	$0
Meeting/Program Supplies. ARHP requests federal funding to purchase meeting and program supplies for initial statewide and regional meetings for $1,000.	$1,010
Laptop Computer. ARHP will provide $1,000 to purchase a laptop for the Project Director.	$0
Total Supplies	$1,010
Travel
Program Implementation. ARHP will provide funding for mileage costs for program implementation, which is calculated @ 2,000/mile per year @ $.655/mile= $1,310/year for all project staff to attend in-person meetings (in-state).	$0
Conference Travel. ARHP requests federal funding for travel expenses for the Project Director to attend a mandatory 1.5-day grant workshop in Washington DC.	$1,398
Total Travel	$1,398
Winthrop Rockefeller Institute (WRI). ARHP will contract WRI to facilitate strategic planning throughout the project. WRI has a team of well-trained and experienced facilitators adept at meeting design and facilitation.WRI, a project network partner, will work with other network members and state stakeholders, to facilitate a statewide day-long meeting, four on-site regional meetings, monthly virtual regional meetings, and four regional and statewide strategic rural workforce plans. Three WRI staff members facilitating 1) a one-day in-person state convening meeting at Winthrop Rockefeller Institute, 2) four in-person regional meetings (3-4 hours), 3) follow-up virtual meetings (approximately 20+
1-2 hour meetings, 4) development and delivery of one state and four regional strategic plans. Includes facilitation, planning, travel to and from meetings, and other associated costs to meet deliverables. Estimated cost @ $34,160/year.	$34,160

recipient_justification: This payment request supports the calculation of indirect costs. Please note this response applies to multiple payment requests, as indirect is a standard payment request. Under the Uniform Guidance (2 CFR 200), the FDOH applies its federally negotiated indirect rate when applicable to all allowable salaries and fringe costs incurred quarterly, unless specified otherwise based on the approved grant terms. The current approved negotiated indirect cost rate is 30.50%, effective 7/1/24 to 6/30/25. Indirect costs represent real expenses incurred by the department that support federally sponsored activities that cannot be directly attributed to a single project. These include, but are not limited to, costs associated with department-wide administrative support, utilities, building maintenance, IT infrastructure, and compliance services. The indirect cost charge ensures that the department can maintain the infrastructure to support the grant activities/implementation. This payment request is consistent with the terms of the grant and reflects only allowable expenses in this calculation. A copy of the negotiated rate agreement is available upon request.

recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $4,365.32 on the Health Resources and Services Administration grant number 5 H30MC24048‐13‐00. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $3,085.47, Fringe Benefits $956.50, and Indirect Costs $323.35 subtotal $4,365.32 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Hemophilia Treatment Centers (SPRANS). The costs fund specialists and other clinicians to promote and improve the comprehensive care of patients with bleeding and clotting disorders. It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.   

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance

recipient_justification:
This drawdown request includes funds for a video monitor, workstation, PC and associated items.
Items:
                Ergotron stand – Monitor stand for the desk
                24” Monitors – Allow for viewing patient, patient records, telehealth interface and other materials simultaneously during care.
                Cable tray – Helps to manage all the wiring for the associated devices
                Streaming camera – Core component of the telehealth visit
                HP workstation – Computer at the core of the telehealth visit
                Network adapter – Needed for internet connection

A core component of the Butler Hospital Short Stay Unit CPF/CDS Project is to create an efficient patient assessment workflow in which a patient could be stepped down to outpatient care or moved onto an inpatient unit. 
o	The Telehealth setup is important to this workflow as it:
-	Allows for continuing care for patients
-	Allows offsite clinical teammates to assess a patient on the unit to help aid in the efficient transition to appropriate treatment
-	Allows for clinical teammates on site to be able to triage potential patients at other locations and help efficiently move a patient through the Butler workflow
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: FOA HRSA-24-110, Community Project Funding/Congressionally Directed Spending (CPF/CDS): Facilities and/or Equip Projects. Program purpose: support the construction and renovation (including movable equip) of health care and other facilities. Project purpose: purchase physical therapy equipment & educational supplies for a Doctor of Physical Therapy (DPT) program. Equip will be used to teach students how to properly use it to develop treatment plans for patients that will improve the patient's endurance, function, flexibility, and movement. Learning how to use the equip & educational supplies also allows students to meet clinical skills competencies in the accredited DPT curriculum. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $1,891.44, Fringe Benefits $586.35, and Indirect Costs $198.22 subtotal $2,676.01 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project, Geriatric Academic Career Awards. The costs fund a clinician to develop a standardized comprehensive wound care curriculum that can be implemented in medical schools and training hospitals across the country. It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the NOFO Announcement HRSA-23-007, 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: Awarded under Funding Opportunity Announcement HRSA-22-043, Graduate Psychology Education Program. The purpose of this program is to train doctoral health service psychology students, interns, and post-doctoral residents in integrated, interdisciplinary behavioral health for placement into community-based primary care settings in high need and high demand areas. The program also supports faculty development in health service psychology. The UCCS PhD program in Clinical Psychology [American Psychological Association (APA)-accredited] seeks to expand training experiences in integrated care with a focus on opioid use disorders for doctoral students within Geropsychology and Trauma tracks. Co-investigator contributes to award objectives 1, 2, and 3. Reimbursement for co-investigator's travel to Collaborative Perspectives on Addiction (CPA) annual conference, in line with approved travel budget for faculty to attend national conferences to present research and network, along with associated indirect costs at the awarded rate.

recipient_justification:
This invoice seeks reimbursement of costs incurred in connection with PMS Subaccount Number - 19IBPC (the “Award”) for work performed between 7/1/2019 through 3/31/2025, as reflected in the payment request submitted on 4/30/2025.  Specifically, the invoice seeks payment in the total amount of $1,011.15. Below is a list specifying the breakdown of each item, service, or expense—along with the corresponding costs—for which we are seeking reimbursement pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Award.  

Item	Cost
Supplies	$936.25
Indirect Costs	$74.90
Total Amount of PMS Subaccount Number	$1,011.15

These costs are reasonable, allowable, and allocable to the Award and have been incurred by Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science. According to the FY 2025 Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) General Terms and Conditions, grant funds must be drawn using the HHS Payment Management System (PMS). 

The objective of the Award is to establish and implement the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science (CDU) Center for Primary Care Training Enhancement (C-PCTE) Program. This program is designed to advance the quality and effectiveness of accredited residency training programs in the fields of family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics, and combined internal medicine and pediatrics (med-peds). The program aims to achieve the following clinical objectives:
•	Enhancement of Residency Training: Develop and refine accredited residency training curricula to incorporate the latest clinical guidelines and evidence-based practices, ensuring that residents are well-prepared to meet the evolving needs of primary care. This includes training programs in family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics or combined internal medicine and pediatrics (med-peds).
•	Clinical Skill Development: Focus on enhancing residents' clinical skills through hands-on training, simulation exercises, and exposure to diverse patient populations, fostering a comprehensive understanding of primary care delivery.
•	Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Promote interdisciplinary collaboration among healthcare professionals to improve patient outcomes and streamline care delivery within healthcare settings.
agency_lead_justification: •	This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.
org_name: CHARLES R DREW UNIVERSITY OF MEDICINE & SCIENCE

Request payment for employee per diem reimbursement, Dr Yogi, for travel  Baltimore, MD to attend the HIPPY National Conference from April 6-9, 2025. All programs funded by the federal Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting (MIECHV) program are required to adhere to an evidence-based service delivery model. To assure that Hawaii HIPPY programs meet the model’s fidelity requirements, it is vital for Mr. Yogi to keep informed of changes to service models providing evidence-based home visiting services within the Your Ohana Network. Attendance at the conference benefits the State by increasing the State’s capacity to support HIPPY home visiting in Hawaii. HIPPY home visiting has demonstrated impacts on child development, school readiness, and positive parenting practices, all of which contribute to healthier families and children in Hawaii. We certify that the travel is allowable and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the NOA.

recipient_justification:
What is the Award for?						
The Purpose of this award is to support Maine Mobile Health Program to increase access to Behavioral health Services through starting or expanding mental health and substance use disorder (SUD) services.  The funds used are for 12-month funding to support two objectives: (1) increasing the number of patients receiving mental health services and (2) increasing the number of patients receiving SUD services, including treatment with medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD).						

What will the funds be used for? The funds will be used to pay for internet connectivity and telephone costs.

Why is it necessary? The costs provide staff with the needed accessibility to meet the goals of the award.

Why do they align with the award? The costs are part of the HRSA-approved budget.

recipient_justification:
The payment request of $350 made on 4/28/2025 is for the reimbursement of the following grant expenditures incurred since our last request: 
Laboratory Equipment: $350

The referenced award (Tick-Borne Disease Prevention - 23CE1HS52191) is an equipment-only grant to expand the University of Maine Tick Lab's capacity to detect and characterize tick-borne pathogens. The $350 charge is related to the purchase of a refrigerated centrifuge (Thermo Scientific Sorvall X4R Pro-MD), which is essential for high-speed clarification of tick samples while maintaining a cold environment that prevents RNA degradation and ensures the accuracy and reliability of subsequent qPCR and sequencing analyses.
agency_lead_justification: This payment request has been reviewed and approved in accordance with applicable federal regulations and the terms of the award.

recipient_justification: Nevada’s Title V MCH Program collaborates across the state to improve the health of families, with an emphasis on women, infants, and children, including children and youth with special health care needs. Title V funding supports health education and disease/injury prevention activities, increasing access to health care services, and planning/implementing strategies to reach target populations. Nevada used the funds per the approved federal grant budget in full compliance with Grant B04MC52938- 01. This draw is requesting reimbursement for costs incurred to the State of Nevada, DHHS, Division of Public and Behavioral Health in support of this project from DHHS: Health Resources and Services Administration. Costs include operational, contractual, supplies, other, and indirect through date of 4/21/25. Personnel and fringe costs were for salaries through 3/30/25.
